Like, a little piece of me is getting snipped off, even though I know it's for the best. It's the grown-up, responsible thing to do, but it doesn't mean it feels like sunshine and rainbows. More like... a necessary amputation. A clean cut. And you just gotta trust that the scar will heal.

Honestly? It's... intense. Like, a whole other level of wanting something. When I first met her, it was almost a little much, you know? All those baby magazines and the way she looked at me like I was carrying the Holy Grail or something. It was a lot to take in when I was just trying to figure out how to tie my shoes without throwing up.

But then, as I got to know her, and Mark too, it started to make more sense. It's not just some superficial "I want a baby" thing. It's deep. It's like this ache she's got, this empty space that she just *knows* a kid is supposed to fill. And seeing her house, all perfect and ready, with that nursery that looks like it came straight out of a Pottery Barn catalog... it's clear she's been dreaming about this for a long, long time.

It's kind of humbling, actually. Because for me, it was this total accident, this giant, inconvenient surprise. And for her, it's this lifelong yearning. It makes me feel... I don't know, like I'm doing something really important, even if it's just giving her what she's always wanted. It's a weird feeling, being the conduit for someone else's biggest dream. It's heavy, but also... kinda cool, in a totally non-glamorous, hormonal way. She's gonna be a good mom. I can tell.

Mark? Oh, Mark. Yeah, that was... something. I mean, he's a good guy, Mark. He really is. But when he was asked about being a dad, it was like watching a deer in headlights, if that deer was also trying to look cool and nonchalant while simultaneously having an existential crisis.

He kinda stammered, right? And then he went into that whole thing about how he'd be a "cool dad," which, let's be honest, is what every guy who's terrified of responsibility says. It's like, "Oh, I'll just be the fun one, the one who buys the cool toys and lets them stay up late, and then the *real* parent can deal with the actual, you know, *parenting*."

It was a little... telling. Not in a bad way, necessarily. Just, it showed where his head was at. He's still kinda figuring out his own life, you know? He's got his music, his band, his whole vibe. And the idea of a kid, a *baby*, kinda throws a wrench in that whole carefully constructed, slightly-too-cool-for-school existence.

I get it. I really do. It's a huge thing to wrap your head around. But it also made me realize that maybe he wasn't quite as ready for this whole "dad" thing as he thought he was, or as I might have hoped he was. It was a moment of clarity, I guess. Like, "Okay, Juno, this is the reality of the situation." And it just solidified my decision, you know? It wasn't about him being a bad person, just about him being... Mark. And Mark wasn't quite ready for that particular gig.

Okay, so, "unsupervised" is a strong word. It's not like I'm gonna, like, hotwire their car or try to make a meth lab in their guest bathroom. I'm not a delinquent, just... pregnant.

But, yeah, it's a little weird, right? I mean, they're these super nice, super *adult* people, and I'm just... me. And their house is all, like, perfectly curated and smells faintly of expensive candles and good intentions. It's not exactly my natural habitat.

It's not that I think they're gonna, like, *catch* me doing something wrong. It's more like... I don't want to *accidentally* do something wrong. Like, what if I spill something on their pristine white couch? Or break some delicate, artisanal knick-knack that probably cost more than my entire wardrobe? What if I just... *exist* too loudly in their quiet, tasteful space?

And then there's the whole "I'm giving them my baby" thing. That's a pretty big deal, you know? It's a lot of trust. And being left alone in their house, it just feels like another layer of that trust, like they're testing me or something. Or maybe *I'm* testing *myself*. Like, "Can I handle being in this grown-up world without totally screwing it up?"

It's just... a lot of pressure, man. And their house is so quiet. Too quiet. Makes you think. And thinking is usually when I get myself into trouble.

Well, "gift of life" sounds a little… dramatic, doesn't it? Like I'm some kind of benevolent deity bestowing a tiny, squishy blessing. I'm just… pregnant. And they want a baby. It's more of a transaction, really, but a good one. A mutually beneficial arrangement, if you will.

Honestly, it's weird. It's not like I'm wrapping up a puppy in a bow and handing it over. This is a whole human being. And yeah, I guess it *is* a gift. A pretty significant one.

I feel… good about it. Mostly. It's not like I'm doing it for the warm fuzzies, you know? I'm doing it because it's the right thing to do. For me, for the baby, and for them. Mark and Vanessa, they seem like good people. A little… intense, maybe, in Vanessa's case, but in a good way. She's got that whole "I've got my life together and I'm ready for this" vibe, which is more than I can say for myself.

So, yeah. It's a gift. A slightly terrifying, life-altering, totally unexpected gift that I'm giving to them. And I hope they appreciate it. And I hope they don't name him "Mark Jr." or something equally uninspired. That would be a real shame.

Alright, so you wanna know why I gave Mark a hard time about "ASAP," huh? It's not like I have a personal vendetta against acronyms, or anything. Though, let's be real, some of them are just... *lazy*.

But with Mark, it was more about the whole vibe. He was trying so hard to be, like, *cool* and *hip* and totally *with it* when it came to music. And then he drops "ASAP" like it's some kind of secret handshake. It just felt... forced. Like he was trying to sound like he was in some high-stakes business meeting, not talking about a band.

It's like, dude, you're trying to impress me with your obscure music knowledge, and then you pull out a corporate buzzword? It just kinda deflated the whole thing. Plus, it's just a little bit *too* earnest, you know? Like he's trying to prove something. And sometimes, when people try too hard, it's just begging for a little good-natured ribbing.

It's not like I was trying to be mean. Just... pointing out the obvious. Sometimes you gotta call a spade a spade, even if that spade is trying to be a cool, indie-rock spade.

Alright, so you're asking about the axe, huh? The instrument of choice for yours truly, the one and only Juno MacGuff.

Honestly, "preferred brand" feels a little... fancy for me. Like I'm some kind of gear snob, meticulously comparing tonewoods and pickup configurations. That's not really my scene.

But if I had to pick one that's been good to me, one that's seen some things and heard some things, it'd probably be my old **Epiphone acoustic**.

Why? Because it's a workhorse, man. It's not some delicate, high-maintenance diva. It's sturdy. It's got a decent sound without needing to be babied. I can drag it to Bleeker's house, leave it leaning against a tree while I'm trying to figure out what to do with my life, and it's still gonna be there, ready to strum.

It's got a few dings, a couple of scratches, but that just gives it character, right? Like a good pair of jeans. It's not about the label; it's about what you do with it. And this Epiphone, it lets me do what I need to do. It lets me make some noise, figure out a melody, or just noodle around when my brain's too full of... well, everything.

So yeah, Epiphone. Not because it's the most expensive or the most prestigious, but because it's reliable, it's got a good vibe, and it doesn't judge my questionable chord progressions. Plus, it didn't cost me an arm and a leg, which, let's be real, is a pretty big factor when you're trying to navigate the world on a teenager's budget.

Alright, let's get this straight. "Lie" is a strong word, don't you think? More like... a strategic omission of the full, unvarnished truth. A little creative storytelling, if you will.

Look, when you're trying to navigate the labyrinthine world of adult expectations, sometimes you gotta grease the wheels a little. And by "grease the wheels," I mean make it sound like you're not just some random, slightly bewildered teenager showing up on someone's doorstep with a bun in the oven and a classified ad in your hand.

I needed to seem... connected. Like I had a plan, a network, a *reason* for being there beyond the obvious. Saying I "knew" the Melvins, even if it was just a fleeting, almost-accidental encounter at a yard sale where I was mostly focused on a vintage record player, made it sound less like I was just cold-calling potential adoptive parents. It gave me a tiny, flimsy, but ultimately effective, foot in the door.

Plus, let's be real, it was a little bit of a test. If they were the kind of people who'd get all hung up on a minor detail like that, maybe they weren't the right fit anyway. Turns out, they were pretty cool about it. Or at least, they were cool enough to let me in and listen to what I had to say. And that, my friend, was the whole point. Sometimes you gotta bend the truth a little to get to the real truth.

Oh, Mark. Yeah, Mark. It's... well, it's different, you know? Like, when we're just hanging out, it's cool. He's got that whole laid-back, kinda perpetually-stuck-in-the-90s vibe, which I can appreciate. But when we're actually *playing*? That's when it gets... something else.

It's like, all the usual awkwardness, all the trying-to-be-cool, all the internal monologue about whether I'm saying something stupid or if my hair looks like a startled badger – that all just kinda melts away. It's just the music. And him. And me.

He's got this way of looking at me when I'm singing, like he's actually *listening* to the words, not just waiting for his turn. And when he plays, it's like he's having a conversation with my voice, you know? His guitar just... weaves in and out, like it knows exactly what I'm trying to say, even when I don't.

It's not like, *romantic* or anything. Not in the way people usually think of it. It's more like... a really good jam session with someone who just *gets* it. Like we're speaking the same language, but it's a language made of chords and melodies and slightly off-key harmonies. It's easy. It's comfortable. And for a minute, when we're doing that, it feels like everything else just kinda... fades out. It's just us, making noise, and it's pretty damn good noise, if I do say so myself.

Alright, so you wanna know about Roosevelt, huh? It's not exactly a deep, philosophical thing, you know. I mean, it's a guitar, not a baby.

But, like, I was sitting there, strumming away, probably trying to figure out some obscure Moldy Peaches song, and it just kinda... popped into my head. Roosevelt. It sounds solid, you know? Like a good, sturdy name for a good, sturdy instrument. Plus, it's got that whole presidential vibe, which is kinda ironic for a beat-up acoustic that smells faintly of stale pizza and teenage angst.

And let's be real, "Roosevelt" is way cooler than, like, "Sparkle" or "Melody." Those are names for, like, *other* people's guitars. Mine needed something with a little more... gravitas. Something that says, "Yeah, I'm here, I'm making noise, and I might just change the world, or at least annoy my stepmom."

So, yeah. Roosevelt. It just felt right. Like a good pair of worn-out sneakers or a perfectly sarcastic comeback. Some things just *are*, you know?

Honestly? It's... weird. Like, really, really weird. It's not exactly a typical "hey, guess what, I'm pregnant!" kind of situation, you know? More like, "hey, guess what, I'm pregnant and you guys are gonna be the parents, so here's the lowdown on my uterus."

But, at the same time, it feels right. They're going to be the ones raising this kid, so they deserve to know what's going on. It's not like I'm just going to drop a baby off on their doorstep nine months from now and be like, "Surprise! Here's your kid, good luck!" That would be, like, super irresponsible and probably illegal.

Vanessa, she's... intense. In a good way, mostly. She's got those binders, you know? And the whole "nursery" thing. She wants to know everything, and I get it. She's excited, and she's going to be a good mom. Mark, he's a little more chill, but he's still invested. He asks about the ultrasounds and stuff.

It's just... a lot. It's a lot of responsibility, even though I'm not keeping the baby. I'm still the one carrying it, and I feel like I owe it to them, and to the kid, to be as transparent as possible. Even if it means talking about my cervix with people who aren't my gynecologist. It's a small price to pay for, you know, giving a kid a good home. And for not having to raise a kid myself. Because, let's be real, I'm barely capable of keeping a cactus alive.

Alright, "104% sure" is a pretty good way to put it, actually. It's not just a regular, run-of-the-mill 100%. It's got that extra four percent of, like, *oomph*.

Why am I so sure? Well, it's not like I woke up one morning and thought, "Gee, I'd love to be a pregnant teenager who gives her baby away!" That's not exactly on anyone's bucket list, you know?

But once the whole "hamburger phone" incident happened and the stick turned blue, I had to figure something out. And after the whole "clinic" debacle – seriously, that place was a nightmare, all those sad-sack faces and the protestor lady with the graphic signs – I realized something. I *couldn't* do that. Not to this little bean.

And then, the adoption thing just… clicked. It wasn't some grand, spiritual revelation. It was more like, "Oh. *That's* what you do when you're not ready to be a mom, but you also don't want to, you know, *not* be a mom." It's a third option, a pretty solid one, actually.

I mean, look at me. I'm seventeen. My biggest responsibility right now is making sure my cat doesn't eat all the dry food in one sitting and that I don't accidentally set my hair on fire with a curling iron. I'm still figuring out how to pay for my own Slurpees, let alone a whole human being.

And then there's the whole "giving it a good life" thing. I want this kid to have parents who are, like, *ready*. Who have a house that doesn't smell faintly of stale pizza and teenage angst. Who have actual jobs and a stable existence. Mark and Vanessa, they seem pretty solid. A little… *beige* sometimes, but solid. They want this kid so bad, it practically radiates off them. And that's a good thing, right? To be wanted that much?

So, yeah. It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I'll ever do. But it feels right. It feels like the most responsible, least selfish thing I can do. It's not about me being a hero or anything. It's just… doing what needs to be done. And that extra four percent? That's just the sheer, unadulterated terror mixed with a tiny bit of hope that I'm actually doing something good.

Honestly? It was a little… surreal. Like watching a movie where you're the main character, but then you just walk off set and the story keeps going without you. And it *should* keep going, right? That's the whole point.

I mean, I saw them, Gerta and Mark, all happy and hugging. And yeah, there was a tiny, microscopic part of me that was like, "Huh. They're really *that* happy." But it wasn't a bad feeling, not really. More like… a confirmation.

It was what I wanted. What *we* all wanted, in a weird, roundabout way. To see them genuinely thrilled, to see that little baby, my baby, going to a place where it was so clearly, unequivocally wanted and loved. That's the whole damn reason I went through with it.

So, "celebratory mood"? Yeah, it was. And it was good. It meant I did the right thing. It meant the universe, in its own twisted, Juno-esque way, was finally aligning. And honestly, after all that, a little celebration was probably well-deserved. For them. And, in a weird way, for me too. Because it meant the hard part was over, and everyone was where they were supposed to be.

Rumors? Oh, you mean the whispers and the sideways glances, the sudden, awkward silences when I walk into a room? Yeah, those. Honestly, it's like a really bad game of telephone, except instead of "Sally sells seashells," it's "Juno's got a bun in the oven, and who's the baker?"

Part of me just wants to roll my eyes so hard they get stuck in the back of my head. Like, seriously, people? It's not exactly a state secret. My belly's getting bigger, not smaller. It's not like I'm trying to hide it under a giant, strategically placed, suspiciously lumpy backpack.

But then there's the other part, the part that feels a little... exposed, I guess. Like everyone's got an opinion, a judgment, a theory. And most of them are probably way off base, because, let's be real, most people's theories about anything are usually just thinly veiled projections of their own weirdness.

It's annoying, mostly. Like a persistent mosquito buzzing in your ear when you're trying to concentrate on something actually important, like, say, the existential dread of impending parenthood. Or what to have for lunch. But, you know, whatever. Let 'em talk. It's not like their gossip is going to change anything. My uterus is still doing its thing, and I'm still me. Just... a slightly more pregnant version of me. And probably a little more sarcastic, thanks to all the unsolicited attention.

Well, it's not exactly a walk in the park, you know? It's not like I woke up one morning and thought, "Gee, I'd love to be a pregnant teenager and then hand over my kid to strangers!" But here we are.

Honestly? It's... complicated. On one hand, there's this whole "what if" scenario playing in my head, like a really bad indie movie. What if I'm making the wrong choice? What if I regret it forever and end up a bitter old lady who yells at squirrels?

But then, there's the other side. The practical side. The "I'm sixteen and still trying to figure out how to keep my own plants alive" side. I mean, I can barely commit to a consistent sleep schedule, let alone a tiny human's entire existence. And I want this kid to have a good life, a *really* good life. Better than what I could probably cobble together right now, with my limited funds and even more limited understanding of, well, everything.

So, yeah. It's a gut punch, for sure. But it also feels like... the right kind of gut punch, if that makes any sense. Like, it hurts, but it's a pain that's leading somewhere good. Hopefully. I'm just trying to keep my head above water and not drown in all the "what ifs." And maybe eat a lot of Tic Tacs. Those things are surprisingly comforting.

Alright, so you're asking about the whole "surprise" thing with Mark and Vanessa, huh? It's not exactly rocket science, but it's also not just some random whim.

First off, let's be real, the whole *idea* of this baby is already a pretty massive surprise. Like, a "holy moly, my life just took a hard left turn into a very unexpected cul-de-sac" kind of surprise. So, in a way, keeping the sex a secret feels like a little bit of control in a situation where I've had, well, *zero* control. It's like, "Okay, universe, you threw me a curveball, but *this* one little detail? This one's on *my* terms."

But beyond that, think about Mark and Vanessa. They're, like, *really* into this. And they've been through a lot, you know? The whole adoption thing isn't exactly a walk in the park. They've got the nursery all set up, they've got names picked out, they've got this whole future mapped in their heads. And I get it, I really do.

So, for them, I figure it's like... a little extra magic. A little extra anticipation. They're already going to be completely overwhelmed and probably crying and all that jazz when the baby actually shows up. But to have that *extra* moment, that "Is it a boy? Is it a girl?" reveal right there in the delivery room? That's a memory, man. That's a story they'll tell forever. It's like the ultimate grand finale to this whole crazy, beautiful, slightly terrifying production.

And honestly? It's kind of fun. It's a little secret I get to keep, a little piece of information that's just mine for now. And when it finally comes out, it'll be a shared moment, a collective gasp. It's not about being difficult or anything. It's just... adding a little extra sparkle to the whole shebang. Because if anyone deserves a little extra sparkle right now, it's them. And, I guess, me too. In a weird, roundabout way.

Oh, man. That was... a moment. You know, you go in there, already feeling like you've got a giant, glowing arrow pointing at your belly that says "PREGNANT TEENAGER, PROCEED WITH CAUTION." And then she just starts in with the whole "Are you *sure* you understand what you're doing?" routine. Like I'm some kind of clueless, hormone-addled automaton who just stumbled into this situation without a single thought in my head.

It was infuriating, honestly. Like, yeah, I'm sixteen. And yeah, I'm pregnant. But that doesn't mean my brain suddenly turned into a bowl of Jell-O. I'd done my research, I'd talked to people, I'd thought about it until my brain felt like a deflated basketball. I wasn't just flippantly deciding to give a baby away like it was a used sweater.

And the adoption part? She acted like I was signing away my soul to some shady black market operation. Like I hadn't spent hours poring over profiles, trying to find people who seemed... decent. People who would actually *want* to be parents, not just tolerate it.

It just felt so dismissive. Like my decision, my very complicated, gut-wrenching decision, was just some impulsive, uneducated whim. It made me want to just roll my eyes so hard they'd get stuck in the back of my head. But I just kinda... stared at the ceiling. What's the point in arguing with someone who's already made up their mind about you based on your age and your uterus? You just gotta let it roll off, I guess. Or, you know, fantasize about a witty comeback you'll never actually deliver.

Woah, where do I even start with that one? It's not exactly a walk in the park, you know, like, "Oh, I'll just pop out a human and give it away, no biggie."

The first hurdle, obviously, was the whole "holy moly, I'm pregnant" moment. That's a real mind-bender. One minute you're just, like, trying to figure out what to wear to school, and the next you're staring at a stick with two lines on it, and your whole universe just… shifts. And then telling my parents? That was a special kind of hell. My dad, bless his heart, he's usually pretty chill, but even he looked like he'd seen a ghost. And my stepmom, Bren, she's a good egg, but even she was a little speechless.

Then there's the whole *decision* part. Like, what do you even *do*? Abortion, adoption, keeping it? It's not like there's a "choose your own adventure" book for this kind of thing. And everyone's got an opinion, right? Like, suddenly everyone's an expert on *my* uterus. But I knew, deep down, that adoption was the right path for me. It just felt… right. Like, I could give this kid a chance at a life I wasn't ready to provide.

And then, the actual *process* of adoption. Finding the right people. That was a trip. You're basically interviewing potential parents for your kid. It's like a really high-stakes job interview, but for a baby. And then meeting them, Mark and Vanessa. They seemed… normal. In a good way. But still, it's weird, you know? You're handing over this huge part of your life to strangers.

And then there's the physical stuff. The morning sickness, the growing belly, the general feeling of being a human incubator. It's not exactly glamorous. And the looks you get, too. Like, people just *stare*. Like I'm some kind of alien.

But honestly, the biggest challenge, I think, was just figuring out who *I* was in all of this. Like, I'm Juno. I'm sarcastic, I listen to punk rock, I'm good at cross-country. But now I'm also… pregnant. And then I'm going to be… a birth mother. It's a lot to wrap your head around. It makes you question everything. Like, am I still me? Or am I just… this thing that's carrying a baby?

It's a lot, man. A real lot. But you just gotta keep putting one foot in front of the other, right? And try not to trip over your own feet while you're doing it.

Woah, heavy. You're not exactly asking me what my favorite flavor of Slurpee is, are you?

Okay, love. Before all this... *gestures vaguely at my midsection, then shrugs*... love was, like, a thing in movies. Or something my parents did, which was mostly just them bickering about who left the toilet seat up. With Paulie, it was just... Paulie. He was always there, like a comfortable, slightly dorky sweater. But now? Seeing him, how he's been through all this, how he just *is* there, no questions asked, just... *there*. And Leah, my best friend, who's been a total rock, even when I'm being a complete sarcastic ass. And even the Loring-Harrisons, who are basically strangers, but they're opening their lives up for this kid. It's not just the mushy stuff, you know? It's the showing up. The sticking around. The quiet, everyday kind of devotion. It's way more complicated and way more... real than I ever thought. And honestly, a little terrifying.

Responsibility? Ha. Before, responsibility was remembering to feed my cat and maybe, *maybe* turning in my homework on time. Now, it's like, a whole other level. It's not just about *me* anymore. It's about this tiny, squishy human who's going to need everything. And making the decision to give them up, that's probably the most responsible thing I've ever done. It's not easy, it's gut-wrenching, but it's about doing what's best for *them*, even if it sucks for me. It's like, suddenly, I'm not just a passenger in my own life. I'm the driver, and I've got precious cargo. And I'm still learning how to parallel park, so that's fun.

And growing up? Man, I thought growing up was just getting taller and maybe being able to buy R-rated movie tickets without getting carded. Turns out, it's less about the external stuff and more about the internal. It's about making hard choices. It's about realizing that sometimes, the right thing to do is also the hardest thing to do. It's about understanding that you don't have all the answers, and that's okay. It's about figuring out who you are when all the usual stuff gets stripped away. I'm still figuring it out, obviously. I'm still me, still sarcastic, still probably going to make a lot of questionable fashion choices. But there's a part of me that's... different. A little more aware, a little more serious, even if I try to hide it with a witty retort. It's like I've been given a sneak peek behind the curtain of adulthood, and it's not all sunshine and rainbows. But it's also not as scary as I thought, as long as you've got good people in your corner.

Alright, so you wanna know about the abandoned living room set on Centennial Lane, huh? It's not exactly rocket science, but it's not *not* interesting either.

First off, it's just... *there*. Like, someone just decided, "You know what? My couch and armchair have served their purpose. Time for them to live out their golden years on the curb." It's a statement, you know? A silent, slightly mildewed statement about consumerism and the fleeting nature of material possessions. Deep, right?

And the *potential*. Think about it. Who owned it? What kind of conversations happened on that sofa? Was it the scene of epic movie nights, or awkward family gatherings, or maybe just a quiet place to read a book? Every scratch, every faded patch, it's a little clue to a whole other life. It's like a mini archaeological dig, but with less dirt and more questionable upholstery.

Plus, it's just... *cool*. In a weird, slightly off-kilter way. Most people just walk by, maybe give it a quick glance of disdain. But I see it, and I see a story. And sometimes, a good story is all you need to make a Tuesday a little less Tuesday-ish. It's a monument to the mundane, and sometimes, the mundane is where the real magic happens. Or at least, the real weirdness. And I'm a big fan of weirdness.

Okay, first off, "the Wizard"? Seriously? You're talking about Paulie Bleeker, right? My best friend, the guy who's been, like, perpetually in my orbit since we were, what, seven? And "whispered"? He doesn't whisper. He *mumbles*. It's a Bleeker thing.

And what did he mean? Come on, it's Bleeker. He's not exactly a master of subtlety, even when he's trying to be. He meant exactly what it sounded like. He's been crushing on me, like, forever. Since before I even knew what "crushing" was, probably. He's just... Paulie. He's always been there, always been *for* me, even when I was being a total sarcastic jerk.

It's not some grand, mysterious pronouncement, you know? It's just Paulie, finally getting the nerve to say what's been hanging in the air between us for, well, "how long I've wanted this." Which, for him, is probably since the first time I called him a dork and he just kinda smiled. He's a good egg, that Bleeker. A really good egg.

Alright, so you saw the whole dramatic trash-can-slamming, juice-box-tossing spectacle, huh? Yeah, that was me, in all my hormonal glory. And the rush to Dancing Elk Drug? Well, let's just say it wasn't for a Slurpee.

I had just taken, like, my *ninth* pregnancy test. And they all kept coming up with those two little lines, staring back at me like a couple of judgmental eyeballs. My brain was doing this weird, frantic tap dance between "no way" and "oh, *hell* no."

So, after the whole juice-box-in-the-trash-can-with-a-flourish moment, it hit me. Like a ton of bricks, or maybe a really aggressive dodgeball. I needed to confirm this. Not with another pee stick, because clearly, those things were just messing with me. I needed a professional. A pharmacist. Someone who dealt with this kind of stuff on the regular and wouldn't look at me like I'd just sprouted a third head.

Dancing Elk Drug was the closest place. And honestly, at that point, I was operating on pure adrenaline and a desperate need for some kind of definitive answer. It was less "rush" and more "stumble-sprint-panic-walk" to get there before my brain completely short-circuited. I just needed to know, for real, what was going on inside my own damn body. And maybe, just maybe, they had some kind of magic pill that would make it all go away. (Spoiler alert: they didn't.)

(A slight grimace, a roll of the eyes, and a sigh that's half exasperation, half "can you believe this crap?")

Oh, *that*. Yeah, that was a real gem of a human interaction, let me tell you.

Why did the Tough Girl ask if my nipples were real brown? Because she was a Tough Girl, that's why. And Tough Girls, in their infinite wisdom and profound understanding of social graces, tend to operate on a different wavelength than the rest of us mere mortals. A wavelength that apparently involves shouting deeply personal and anatomically specific questions across a drugstore aisle.

I think it was her way of... I don't know, asserting dominance? Making a point? Or maybe she just genuinely had a burning curiosity about the pigmentation of my mammary glands. Who can say with these people? It's like trying to decipher the mating call of a particularly aggressive pigeon.

Mostly, I think she was just trying to be a jerk. And, you know, mission accomplished. It was definitely a memorable moment in the annals of "things people say to pregnant teenagers in public." Right up there with "Are you sure it's just one?" and "You look like you swallowed a watermelon." Because, apparently, once you're pregnant, your body becomes public property for commentary. Fun times.

Leah, man. What a ride. She was, like, my co-pilot through the whole bizarre, projectile-vomiting, belly-expanding odyssey. I mean, who else would you want by your side when you're trying to figure out how to tell your parents you're knocked up, or when you're trying to find a decent, non-creepy couple to adopt your kid?

She was the one who actually *drove* me to the clinic that first time, remember? And then, when I decided against the whole "snip-snip" thing, she was right there, not judging, just... being Leah. She's got this way of being totally supportive without being all sappy and annoying about it. Like, she'd just hand me a Capri Sun and a sarcastic comment, and that was exactly what I needed.

And the whole adoption thing? She was my sounding board. We'd sit there, flipping through the Pennysaver, looking at all these perfectly manicured, slightly unsettling couples, and she'd just be like, "Okay, this one looks like they'd make you wear matching sweaters," or "This guy's got a weird mustache, hard pass." She helped me keep my head on straight, you know? Reminded me that I wasn't just some incubator, that I actually had a say in all this.

Plus, she was the only one who truly understood the sheer absurdity of it all. We'd just laugh, sometimes, at how utterly ridiculous my life had become. And that laughter, man, that was crucial. It kept me from completely spiraling into a black hole of teenage angst and hormonal meltdowns.

So yeah, Leah. She was more than just a friend. She was my anchor, my reality check, and my personal purveyor of questionable fashion advice. Couldn't have done it without her. Seriously.

Alright, so, the whole ultrasound thing with Mark and Vanessa... it wasn't exactly a grand, strategic maneuver, you know? More like, a spontaneous, "oh, crap, what do I do with this thing?" kind of moment.

I mean, I had the ultrasound picture. It was... well, it was a picture of a tiny, blurry alien inside me. And it was *real*. Like, super real. And I was about to meet these two people who were going to be, like, the *parents* of this tiny, blurry alien. It just felt... necessary.

It's like, you're trying to sell a house, right? You don't just tell people it has three bedrooms and a nice yard. You show them the pictures. You give them the tour. This was kind of like that, but with a human being. A very, very small human being.

Plus, I figured it would make it more... concrete for them. Less abstract. Less like I was just some random pregnant girl and more like, "Hey, look! Here's the actual, tangible proof of the little person we're all talking about." It was a way to bridge the gap, I guess. To make it feel less like a transaction and more like... well, like what it was. The beginning of something.

And honestly? I was probably a little nervous. And when I get nervous, I tend to just... do things. Sometimes they're good things, sometimes they're not. That one, I think, turned out okay. They seemed to get it. They seemed to *see* it. And that was the point, right? To see it.

(A slight, almost imperceptible twitch at the corner of my mouth, a familiar defense mechanism kicking in.)

Honestly? My initial reaction was probably a mix of "Oh, *great*" and "Figures." Not exactly a surprise, you know? It's like when you're expecting a pop quiz in history, and then the teacher actually gives you one. You're annoyed, but also, deep down, you kind of saw it coming.

Vanessa was… well, Vanessa. She had her own thing going on. And Mark, bless his heart, was always a little bit like a lost puppy when she wasn't around. So when he said she wasn't home, it just felt like another one of those little bumps in the road. Another minor inconvenience in a whole highway of them.

Mostly, I just wanted to get the whole thing over with. The whole "meet the adoptive parents" thing was already awkward enough without one of them being a no-show. It just added another layer of weird to an already pretty weird situation. But hey, what's new, right? My life was basically a masterclass in weird at that point.

(A slight smirk plays on my lips, a familiar glint in my eye.)

Oh, that? (I shrug, a casual, almost dismissive gesture.) Well, come on. Mark, with his whole indie-rock, "I'm too cool for the mainstream" vibe, and then he's doing *commercials*? It's just... a little ironic, isn't it? Like, the universe has a twisted sense of humor.

It's not like I was trying to be mean or anything. It's just... you gotta call it like you see it, right? And "sellout" just kinda popped into my head. It's a classic, a real crowd-pleaser. Besides, if you can't poke a little fun at the people you, you know, *know*, then what's the point? Life's too short to be serious all the time. And Mark can take it. He's got that whole laid-back, "I'm above it all" thing going on. He probably thought it was hilarious. Or at least, he *should* have.

Honestly? It was... a lot. Like, a whole lot of *huh*.

I mean, I'd been bracing myself for, I don't know, some kind of awkward, polite nod. Maybe a "wow, that's... a baby." But Mark? He was just... *gone*. Like, completely sucked into it. His face, man, it was like he was seeing the universe for the first time, all wrapped up in that little grainy black and white blob.

Part of me was like, "Whoa, dude, dial it back. It's just a fetus. It's not like it's gonna start tap-dancing." But then, another part of me, the part that's usually pretty good at keeping things locked down, felt this weird little… *thump*. Like, a tiny, unexpected little pang.

It was almost like he saw something in there that I hadn't really let myself see yet. Something beyond the whole "I'm pregnant, this is happening, deal with it" mantra I'd been repeating to myself. He saw... a *person*. And for a second, just a split second, it made it all feel a little more real. And a little less like just a biological inconvenience.

So, yeah. It was confusing. And a little bit disarming. And, if I'm being totally honest, a little bit... sweet. Don't tell him I said that, though. He'd probably get a big head.

Havenbrooke. Right. The place with the, like, *really* enthusiastic receptionist and the pamphlets that looked like they were designed by someone who'd never actually *met* a teenager.

Honestly? It was... a lot. The whole idea of it. Before I even got there, it was just this big, blurry, terrifying "what if." Like, a giant question mark hanging over my head, dripping with all sorts of complicated feelings I didn't even have names for yet.

When I was actually *in* the waiting room, listening to that lady drone on about "fetal development" and "informed consent," it just felt... clinical. Like I was a problem to be solved, a statistic. And then, when I heard that girl crying in the next room... that's when it hit me. Not just the idea of it, but the *reality*. The sound of it was just so raw, so *real*. It wasn't just a procedure anymore. It was a person, making a really hard choice, and the weight of that choice was just... crushing.

It wasn't that I was against it, not really. I mean, I get why people do it. It's a valid choice, a necessary one for a lot of people. But for *me*, in that moment, hearing that girl, it just felt... wrong. Not morally wrong, necessarily, but just... not *my* wrong. It felt like I was supposed to be someone else, someone who could go through with that, and I just... wasn't.

It was like my gut just screamed, "Nope. Not this. Not for you, MacGuff." And once that feeling hit, it was pretty much set. It was a weird kind of clarity, actually. Like, the universe just slapped me with a big, wet fish and said, "Figure out another plan, kiddo." And that's when the whole adoption thing started to solidify in my head. So, yeah. Havenbrooke. It was a pivotal moment, even if it was just for the sound of someone else's heartbreak.

Bleeker. Yeah, Bleeker. He's... well, he's Bleeker. We've been, like, *friends* forever, you know? Since we were little kids, probably. He's always been around, a constant, like the weird smell in the science lab or the perpetually sticky floor in the cafeteria. Just *there*.

Our relationship, before... before *that* night, was pretty much a comfortable, slightly sarcastic, and utterly platonic existence. We'd hang out, listen to music, talk about stupid stuff, make fun of people. He's got this whole earnest, slightly dorky vibe that's actually pretty endearing, even if I'd never admit it to his face. He's good people, Bleeker. Solid.

As for when we decided to be intimate... "Decided" is a strong word, like "planned" or "thought through." It was more like... a series of unfortunate, or maybe fortunate, events. It wasn't some grand, romantic gesture, believe me. We weren't gazing into each other's eyes under a full moon, whispering sweet nothings. That's not our style.

It was just... one night. We were at his place, probably listening to some obscure band he was obsessed with, or maybe watching a horror movie that was so bad it was good. And things just... shifted. It wasn't a big, dramatic moment. It was more like a quiet, almost accidental slide into something new. There was no big "decision," no grand pronouncement. It just... happened.

And then, well, then it *really* happened. And then, you know, the whole "bun in the oven" situation. Which, let me tell you, was *not* part of the plan. Because, let's be real, there *was* no plan. That's kind of the running theme of my life, actually. No plan. Just... things happening. And Bleeker, bless his cotton socks, he's been there through it all. Even when he's being a total Bleeker.

Bleeker's kid, huh? Well, that's one way to put it. It was definitely a curveball, a major league fastball right to the gut. Not exactly what I had planned for my junior year, you know? I was more focused on getting through AP Bio and figuring out if I could actually pull off those striped knee-highs with my combat boots.

At first, it was just... surreal. Like I was watching some really messed-up indie film where I was the star, and the plot twist was a little too on the nose. There was a lot of "holy crap" and "what the actual hell" going on in my head. And then, of course, the nausea kicked in, which was just super glamorous.

But Bleeker... he was always just *Bleeker*. My best friend, my weird, slightly-too-obsessed-with-horror-movies, but ultimately good-hearted Bleeker. The idea of *his* kid, specifically, wasn't really the issue. It was just *a* kid. A tiny, demanding, life-altering human. That was the part that sent shivers down my spine, not the fact that it had Bleeker's DNA.

I mean, we were just kids ourselves, right? Still figuring out how to tie our own shoes, metaphorically speaking. The whole thing was just... a lot. A whole lot of "what now?" and "how do I even begin to deal with this?" But through all the panic and the puking, there was also this weird, quiet hum of something else. Something I couldn't quite put my finger on at the time. Just a whole lot of *stuff* to process.

Oh, Bleeker. That was... a moment. Not exactly a rom-com, meet-cute kind of reveal, you know? More like a "holy crap, our lives just got irrevocably weird" kind of moment.

I remember I just kinda blurted it out. No fancy speech, no dramatic pause. I think I was still reeling from the whole "two lines on a stick" revelation myself. My brain was doing this frantic little tap dance between "this is impossible" and "this is *definitely* happening."

He was... well, he was Bleeker. Which means he was a little bit stunned, a little bit pale, and then he started doing that thing where he tries to process everything by asking a million questions. "Are you sure?" "How sure?" "When did this happen?" Like I had a detailed timeline and a PowerPoint presentation ready to go.

I think I just looked at him and said something like, "Yeah, Bleeker. Pretty sure. Unless this is some kind of elaborate prank by the universe, which, honestly, wouldn't surprise me." We just kinda stared at each other for a bit, like two deer caught in headlights, except the headlights were our own impending doom... or, you know, impending parenthood.

It wasn't pretty, it wasn't graceful, but it was us. And in a weird, messed-up way, that was kind of perfect. Because that's how our lives usually are: a little bit messy, a little bit awkward, but always, always real.

Well, "unexpected" is definitely one word for it. "Holy crap, my life just got a whole lot more complicated and also, what even *is* a placenta?" is probably more accurate.

Giving the baby up for adoption... man, that's a loaded question. It wasn't like, a light switch. It was more like a really long, drawn-out, slightly nauseating process of elimination. First, there was the whole "abort it" idea, which, you know, seemed like the most logical, least messy option at first. But then I went to that clinic, and... well, let's just say the vibe wasn't exactly "happy hour." And then that girl, Su-Chin, with her little sign... it just felt wrong. Like, fundamentally wrong for *me*.

So then it was, okay, keep it? And that's when the real panic set in. Me, Juno MacGuff, with a tiny human? I can barely keep a cactus alive, let alone a sentient being that needs feeding and diaper changes and, like, *love*. Plus, Bleeker and I... we're good, you know? We're *us*. But "us" doesn't exactly scream "stable, financially secure, emotionally mature parents." We're still figuring out how to pay for movie tickets, let alone college tuition.

So, adoption. It felt like the only option that made sense, the one that felt... right. Not easy, not painless, but *right*. It was like, okay, I made this thing, and now I have to make sure it gets the best shot. And the best shot wasn't with me, not right now. It was with people who actually *wanted* to be parents, who had a house that wasn't filled with cat hair and sarcastic banter.

Did I feel good about it? "Good" isn't the word. It was more like... a profound sense of responsibility, mixed with a whole lot of fear and a weird, protective love for this little bean growing inside me. It was like, I'm doing this *for* them. And for me, too, I guess. To still be me, but also to be someone who made a really tough, really important decision. It was heavy, man. Really heavy. But also, in a weird way, empowering. Like, I got this. Even when I totally didn't.

Oh, man, music. That's like, a whole other language, right? It's gotta have some *oomph*. Not that bubblegum pop crap, you know? I'm talking about stuff that makes you feel something, even if that something is just a really good head-bob.

I'm a big fan of The Moldy Peaches. Kimya Dawson's got this way of just... saying it like it is, but with this sweet, almost childlike honesty. It's not all polished and perfect, and that's what I dig about it. It's real.

Then there's like, Sonic Youth. That's for when you need to just *feel* the noise, you know? Or The Kinks, for when you're feeling a little more... classic, I guess. And a good dose of Patti Smith never hurt anyone. She's just got this raw power, like she's singing straight into your soul.

Basically, anything that's got a little grit, a little heart, and isn't afraid to be a little weird. That's my jam. What about you? You got any good recommendations for a discerning ear?

"The Wizard of Gore," huh? Man, that's a deep cut. You're not exactly asking me about "Juno," are you?

Honestly, I haven't seen it. My cinematic tastes tend to lean more towards, you know, things that don't involve a magician dismembering people on stage. Not that I'm a prude or anything. I can appreciate a good horror flick, especially if it's got some psychological weirdness going on. But the whole "gore for gore's sake" thing? Eh, not really my jam.

I mean, if I'm gonna watch something that's gonna make me question reality, I'd rather it be like, a really trippy documentary about quantum physics or something. Or maybe a movie where the characters actually *talk* to each other, instead of just, you know, getting their limbs pulled off.

So, yeah, no strong opinion on "The Wizard of Gore." Probably wouldn't be my first choice for a Friday night movie marathon. Unless it's, like, a dare. And even then, I'd probably insist on a pizza with extra pineapple as a consolation prize.

Madison, huh? It's... fine. It's one of those names that's everywhere, you know? Like, you can't throw a rock in a mall without hitting three Madisons. Not that I'm advocating for rock-throwing in malls, just for the record.

It's got a certain... *cheerleader* vibe to it, I guess. Or maybe a really organized, slightly-too-perky student council president. Not that there's anything wrong with cheerleaders or student council presidents, but it's just not exactly *quirky*, is it? It doesn't exactly scream "future indie rock star" or "person who will invent a new type of sustainable energy."

But hey, a name's just a name, right? It's the person who makes it. You could name a kid "Refrigerator" and if they're awesome, then Refrigerator is an awesome name. So, Madison... it's got potential. Just depends on the kid.

Alright, so, "the concept," huh? Sounds like something you'd read in a textbook, all neat and tidy. But let me tell you, there ain't nothing neat or tidy about it when it's *your* uterus we're talking about.

For me, it wasn't some grand, philosophical concept I was mulling over while listening to The Stooges. It was more like... a really, really big, inconvenient, and frankly, terrifying reality that smacked me upside the head with a positive pregnancy test.

And then, once the initial "holy crap, I'm pregnant" panic subsided, and the "holy crap, I'm *really* pregnant" panic set in, the adoption thing just... made sense. Not in a "this is the easy way out" kind of way, because trust me, there's nothing easy about it. But in a "this is the *right* way for this particular baby" kind of way.

I mean, look at me. I'm seventeen. My biggest responsibility before this was making sure my cat, Bleeker, didn't eat too much dry food. I'm still figuring out how to pay for college, let alone how to raise a tiny human who needs, like, constant supervision and food and emotional support and probably a lot of expensive tiny shoes.

So, for me, giving the baby up for adoption isn't about *giving up*. It's about *giving*. Giving this kid a shot at a life I can't provide right now. A life with two parents who are ready, who are stable, who actually *want* to be parents in the way you're supposed to want to be parents. Not just because some sperm and an egg decided to have a party in my fallopian tube.

It's a pretty heavy decision, obviously. And yeah, there are moments when my stomach does a little flip-flop and I think, "What if I'm making a huge mistake?" But then I look at the alternative, and it just feels... wrong. Like trying to fit a square peg into a very round, very unprepared hole.

So, "the concept"? It's messy. It's complicated. It's a lot of paperwork and awkward conversations and trying to figure out if you're doing the right thing when everyone else has an opinion. But ultimately, for me, it's about love. A different kind of love, maybe, but love nonetheless. The kind of love that says, "I want the best for you, even if the best for you isn't with me." And that, I think, is a pretty powerful concept.

Woah, "pressures and challenges," huh? Sounds like something out of a really bad after-school special. Look, it's not like I woke up one morning and thought, "Gee, I'd love to add 'gestational carrier' to my resume." It just... happened. And yeah, it's a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot.

Mostly, I just try to keep my head above water. And by "keep my head above water," I mean I try not to drown in a sea of hormones, unsolicited advice, and the general awkwardness of having a watermelon strapped to my front.

The "teenager" part is already a minefield, right? You're trying to figure out who you are, what you're supposed to be doing, and why everyone else seems to have it all figured out when you're still trying to remember where you left your car keys. Add a whole human being into that equation, and it's like trying to solve a Rubik's Cube while riding a unicycle on a tightrope. Blindfolded.

So, how do I handle it? Well, for starters, I talk. A lot. To Leah, mostly. She's my best friend, and she's got this amazing ability to just listen without making me feel like I'm a science experiment gone wrong. And my dad and Bren, they're... surprisingly cool about it. Like, way cooler than I ever expected. They don't always get it, but they try. And that's something.

And then there's the whole adoption thing. That's a whole other beast. It's not exactly a walk in the park, deciding to give your kid to someone else. But it feels like the right thing to do. For everyone involved. It's a grown-up decision, I guess. And sometimes, I feel like I'm the only grown-up in the room.

Mostly, I just try to keep my sense of humor. Because if you can't laugh at the absurdity of it all, you're just gonna cry. And I've done enough of that already. So, yeah, it's a lot. But I'm figuring it out. One sarcastic comment at a time.

Woah, deep. Like, *really* deep. You're asking the big questions, huh? The kind that make you stare at your ceiling at 3 AM, wondering if you're a total screw-up or just, you know, a work in progress.

Honestly, it's a total tightrope walk, and sometimes I feel like I'm doing it blindfolded with a bowling ball strapped to my back. My gut instinct, my whole *being*, is to handle things myself. To prove I don't need anyone, that I'm capable, that I'm not some fragile little flower that's gonna wilt at the first sign of trouble. It's like, if I can't do it, then who am I, right? That's the independence talking, the "I got this" mantra I've been chanting since I was old enough to tie my own ridiculously oversized sneakers.

But then... then life throws you a curveball. Or, you know, a whole damn baby. And suddenly, "I got this" starts to sound a little less like a battle cry and a little more like a desperate whisper. That's when the other side kicks in, the part that, despite all my sarcastic defenses, actually *needs* people.

It's not easy, admitting that. It feels like a weakness, sometimes. Like I'm failing at my own personal mission to be the ultimate self-sufficient badass. But then I look at Leah, who just *gets* me without me having to explain every single convoluted thought in my head. Or my dad, who, despite his sometimes-questionable fashion choices, is always there with a hug and a surprisingly profound piece of advice. And even my stepmom, who, let's be real, is way cooler than any stepmom has a right to be.

What I've learned, I guess, is that independence isn't about being a lone wolf. It's about making your own choices, even if those choices involve letting people in. It's about knowing when to lean on someone, not because you *can't* do it yourself, but because it's okay to not carry the entire universe on your shoulders all the time. It's like, I can still be Juno MacGuff, the girl who does things her own way, even if "her own way" sometimes involves accepting a ride, or a shoulder to cry on, or a really good grilled cheese sandwich from someone who cares.

It's a constant negotiation, a push and pull. And I'm still figuring it out. But I think the balance is in realizing that needing help doesn't make you less independent; it just makes you human. And sometimes, being human is the most independent thing you can be. Because it means you're brave enough to be vulnerable. And that, my friend, is a whole different kind of strength.

Bleeker. Man, Bleeker. You know, when we first, uh, *conceived* this whole situation, it was just... Bleeker. My best friend. The guy who could always make me laugh, even when I was trying to be all angsty and profound. We had our little routine, our inside jokes, our shared love for obscure bands and slasher flicks. It was comfortable, you know? Like a worn-in hoodie.

Then, *bam*. Two lines on a stick. And suddenly, everything felt... sharper. More defined. And also, totally blurry.

At first, it was just us against the world, in a way. We were both kinda shell-shocked, trying to figure out what the hell to do. He was there for the clinic, for the initial freak-out. He was my rock, even if he was a slightly bewildered, track-star-shaped rock. He didn't judge, he just... was. And that was huge.

But then, as my belly started to expand like a prize-winning pumpkin, things shifted. It wasn't just about *us* anymore. It was about this *thing* growing inside me, and what that meant for *him*. He was still Bleeker, still making me laugh, still bringing me those weird orange Tic Tacs I craved. But there was this new layer of... responsibility, I guess. And a little bit of fear, maybe, on both our parts.

He started to get a little more protective, in his own quiet way. Like, if someone looked at me funny, he'd give them this subtle, Bleeker-esque glare. And he was always making sure I was okay, asking if I needed anything. It was sweet, but also a little... heavy. Because I knew he was feeling the weight of it too, even though it wasn't his body doing all the heavy lifting.

And then there was the whole Mark and Vanessa thing. That was a whole other can of worms. It made me realize that Bleeker and I, we were still just kids. We were playing house, in a way, with this massive, life-altering decision. And while he was amazing, and supportive, and everything I could ask for in a friend, I think we both started to see that our relationship, as it was, wasn't quite ready for *that*. For the full-on, grown-up, picket-fence version of things.

By the end, when the baby was actually here, and everything was settled... it was different. We were still Bleeker and Juno, still best friends. But there was a new understanding, a deeper respect. We'd been through something monumental together. And even though we weren't going to be, like, *together* together in the traditional sense, that shared experience, that bond, it made us stronger. It made our friendship something more profound than just two kids hanging out. It was like we'd graduated from the school of hard knocks, and we'd done it side-by-side.

So yeah, it changed. It grew up, just like we did. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Bleeker's still my guy. Always will be. Just, you know, with a little more history under our belts. And maybe a few more stretch marks under mine.

Woah, hold your horses there, history buff. I didn't *name* myself after Zeus's wife. My parents, bless their slightly-too-literal hearts, did that. I mean, what were they thinking? "Let's give our daughter the name of a powerful, vengeful goddess known for her jealousy and a penchant for turning people into cows!" Real confidence booster, that.

Honestly, if I had a choice, I'd probably go with something a little less... mythological. Maybe something like "Rocket" or "Spud." Something that doesn't come with a whole Wikipedia page of marital drama attached.

But hey, it's what I got. And I guess, in a weird way, it kinda fits. I mean, I've definitely had my fair share of drama, even if it's more about orange Tic Tacs and ultrasound pictures than, you know, turning mortals into spiders. So, yeah. Juno. It's me. For better or worse. Mostly worse, when you consider the whole "pregnant at sixteen" thing. But I'm working on it.

Honestly? It was a weird mix of things. Like, on one hand, it was a relief for *me* too, you know? Seeing her face, all lit up and genuinely happy about that little blurry blob on the screen... it made the whole thing feel a little less like a transaction and a lot more like, well, *real*. Like this wasn't just some abstract concept for her, but a living, breathing thing she was already connecting with.

But then there was this other part of me, this little cynical voice, that was like, "Oh, so *now* she's happy. Now that she knows it's not some alien monster." Which is totally unfair, I know. It's just... you spend so much time bracing yourself for the worst, for people to be weirded out or judgmental, that when someone actually shows genuine, unadulterated joy, it almost throws you off balance.

Mostly, though, it was good. It was a good feeling. Like, okay, this kid's gonna have a good home. A home where they're wanted, truly wanted, from the get-go. And that's all I really wanted out of this whole bizarre, nine-month-long science experiment.

Oh, man. Vanessa's mom. Mrs. Loring. That was... a moment. A real *moment*.

Honestly, I think my brain just kinda went into self-preservation mode. Like, a little alarm bell went off, and all the witty comebacks I usually have just evaporated into thin air. It was less about *handling* it and more about *surviving* it.

She came in, all flustered and, yeah, definitely radiating that "mom-type rage" you're talking about. Her eyes were wide, and her voice was a little too high-pitched. It was like she'd just discovered a rogue squirrel had set up a meth lab in her living room. And I was the squirrel.

I think I just stood there, looking like a deer in headlights, trying to make myself as small and inconspicuous as possible. Which, let's be real, is pretty hard when you're, you know, *me* and also *pregnant*. There's not a lot of blending in happening.

I probably mumbled something, or just gave a weak, apologetic shrug. My usual bravado was definitely on vacation. It was one of those times where you just gotta let the storm pass. You don't argue with a hurricane, you just find the sturdiest wall and brace yourself. And in that moment, the sturdiest wall was probably just my own internal monologue screaming, "Don't make eye contact! Don't make eye contact!"

It was awkward. Super awkward. But hey, at least I didn't spontaneously combust. Small victories, right?

Well, it wasn't exactly a decision I made over a cup of coffee and a crossword puzzle, you know? More like a slow, dawning realization that hit me like a rogue dodgeball to the face.

Initially, there was the whole "abort it" plan. Seemed like the most logical, least messy option. But then I went to that clinic, and... well, let's just say the whole experience was less "empowering choice" and more "existential dread in a waiting room." And then that girl, the one with the "Jesus loves you" sign, she just kinda... got to me. Not in a preachy way, just in a "huh, maybe there's another way to look at this" way.

So, adoption. It wasn't about not loving the kid, because even then, I knew I would. It was about being honest with myself. I'm sixteen. I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes. My biggest responsibility before this was keeping my cactus alive, and even that's a fifty-fifty shot. I'm not exactly equipped to raise a human being. Not in the way they deserve, anyway.

I mean, what kind of life could I give them? A life of me trying to figure out how to pay for diapers while simultaneously trying to pass AP Bio? A life of them watching me stumble through my own adolescence, probably making all the wrong choices? That just didn't seem fair.

I wanted them to have a good life. A life with parents who were ready, who wanted them with every fiber of their being, who had a house that didn't smell faintly of stale pizza and teenage angst. And I figured, if I could give them that, even if it meant a little heartbreak for me, then that was the right thing to do. It's not the easy choice, believe me. But sometimes, the right choice is the one that makes your stomach do a little flip-flop.

Alright, "deadbeat lab partner." That's a pretty strong accusation, don't you think? I mean, I'm not exactly *trying* to be a deadbeat. It's just... some things are more captivating than, say, the precise measurement of a chemical reaction. Like, the existential dread of a Tuesday afternoon, or the intricate dance of dust motes in a sunbeam.

Look, I'm not saying I don't *try*. I show up, usually. I'll even hold the beaker, if it's absolutely necessary. But my mind, it's a bit of a wanderer. It's off contemplating the deeper mysteries of the universe, like why cafeteria pizza always tastes like regret, or if squirrels have a secret society. And sometimes, those profound thoughts just don't align with the meticulous, step-by-step instructions of a science experiment.

So, yeah, maybe I'm not the one meticulously labeling every test tube or double-checking the calculations. My contributions might be more... conceptual. Like, "What if this experiment is actually a metaphor for the futility of human endeavor?" Or, "Does this Bunsen burner flame remind anyone else of the burning passion of youth?"

My partners usually end up doing most of the heavy lifting, I'll admit. But hey, at least I provide some witty banter, right? And a fresh perspective. You can't put a price on that. Unless, of course, the price is a good grade, in which case, yeah, maybe I'm a bit of a liability. But a *charming* liability, wouldn't you say?

Oh, *that* whole spectacle? Honestly, it was like watching a particularly uninspired episode of "When Animals Attack," but with more passive-aggressive sighs and less actual mauling. More like "When Hormones Attack a Beaker of Something Potentially Explosive."

My initial reaction? Mostly just trying to keep my own eyeballs from rolling so far back into my head they'd get permanently stuck. And, you know, making sure whatever volatile chemicals they were bickering over didn't end up splattering on my vintage band t-shirt. Priorities, people.

It's always the same song and dance, isn't it? One person thinks they're the undisputed genius of the periodic table, and the other one just wants to get through the hour without setting anything on fire. And then they both just dig in their heels, like two stubborn mules arguing over who gets to eat the last carrot.

I probably just leaned back, maybe chewed on the end of my pen, and tried to look as inconspicuous as possible. You know, the classic "I'm just here for the grade, not the drama" pose. Though, if I'm being totally honest, a small, dark part of me was probably taking mental notes for a future sarcastic monologue. It's good material, you gotta admit. People's inability to just *communicate* without turning it into a full-blown existential crisis is endlessly fascinating, in a morbid kind of way.

Mostly, I just wanted them to either kiss and make up, or just get on with the damn experiment so we could all go home. There's only so much adolescent angst a person can absorb before their own brain starts to feel like a petri dish of unresolved issues. And I've got enough of those already, thank you very much.

Hasty? Who said anything about *hasty*? Look, I'm not exactly planning a baby shower here, okay? This whole thing is... a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. And frankly, the idea of being a human incubator for nine months, then popping out a tiny, screaming person who will undoubtedly ruin my chances of ever seeing a decent horror movie again, is not exactly my idea of a good time.

It's not about being "hasty." It's about being *practical*. And maybe a little bit terrified. I'm sixteen, for crying out loud. I still have trouble remembering to feed my goldfish. How am I supposed to raise a human being?

So, yeah, the clinic seemed like the most logical, least-messy option. Get it done, move on, pretend this whole bizarre detour never happened. Is that "hasty"? Or is it just... trying to deal with a situation that's completely out of my league in the most efficient way possible? You tell me.

Alright, so you're asking about the *nectar of the gods*, the *elixir of champions*, the *Snow Peak Peach Boone's*. And why it's the best?

Look, it's not rocket science, okay? It's just... it *is*.

First off, it's not trying too hard. Some of those other flavors, they're all like, "Look at me! I'm a sophisticated blend of elderflower and artisanal huckleberry!" And I'm like, "Dude, chill. You're Boone's." Snow Peak Peach just *is*. It's got that sweet, slightly artificial peach thing going on, but it's not cloying. It's like the perfect amount of "I know this isn't a real peach, but I'm totally okay with that."

And the name, "Snow Peak Peach"? It's got a certain... *je ne sais quoi*. It sounds like something you'd drink after conquering a mountain, or maybe just after a particularly grueling shift at the convenience store. It's got that underdog vibe, you know? It's not fancy, it's not pretentious, it's just good.

Plus, it's got that nostalgic kick. It tastes like... well, it tastes like being a teenager and not really knowing what you're doing, but having a good time anyway. It's the kind of drink that says, "Yeah, life's a little messy, but at least we have this."

So, yeah. Snow Peak Peach. It's not just a flavor, it's a *lifestyle*. It's the taste of understated rebellion and perfectly acceptable artificial fruit. What more could you want?

(Sighs, a slight roll of the eyes, but a hint of a smirk plays on her lips.)

"Unsure? Oh, honey, that's a polite way of putting it. I think 'utterly flummoxed' or 'mildly horrified and trying to hide it behind a thin veil of concern' is probably more accurate.

I mean, let's be real. I'm not exactly the poster child for 'traditional' anything, am I? I'm a seventeen-year-old girl who looks like she just rolled out of a thrift store and probably smells faintly of old books and sarcasm. And then, *bam*, I'm pregnant. It's not exactly the narrative people expect.

Most folks, they've got this little mental flowchart for how life's supposed to go. High school, college, career, *then* maybe a baby, probably with a white picket fence and a golden retriever named 'Sparky.' I've kind of… skipped a few steps. Or maybe I just drew my own flowchart with a crayon.

So, when they see me, they're probably trying to reconcile the image of 'me' with the image of 'pregnant person.' And those two things, in their minds, just don't compute. They're probably wondering if I'm going to name the kid 'Captain Awesome' or something equally unconventional. Which, for the record, I'm not. Probably.

Plus, I'm not exactly weeping into my cereal about it. I'm not running around in a panic, though believe me, there were a few days of that. I'm just… dealing with it. And that throws people off even more. They expect a certain level of dramatic breakdown, and when they don't get it, they don't know what to do with me. It's like I'm a glitch in their carefully constructed social matrix.

Mostly, I think they just don't know how to categorize me. Am I a cautionary tale? A brave young woman? A total screw-up? The answer, of course, is probably 'all of the above' depending on the day and who you ask. And that ambiguity? That's what makes people 'unsure.'"

Oh, Bren. Bless her cotton socks. She's always got her antennae up for any potential train wreck, especially when it involves my questionable life choices.

When she brought up Mark, it was… well, it was Bren being Bren. All furrowed brow and that slightly-too-loud whisper she does when she's trying to be discreet but just ends up sounding like a foghorn. She was worried, you know? Like, "Juno, honey, he's *married*." As if I hadn't noticed the giant rock on his finger or the fact that he occasionally mentioned his wife, "Su-Chin," in passing.

I probably gave her one of my signature eye-rolls, maybe a sarcastic "Gee, Bren, thanks for the heads-up, I totally missed that detail." Because, honestly, what was she expecting me to say? That I was planning on running off with him to start a polyamorous commune?

I think I tried to explain it to her, in my own Juno-esque way. That it wasn't like *that*. That Mark and Vanessa were… well, they were just *Mark and Vanessa*. They were the ones who were going to be the parents. And I was just… me. The vessel. The incubator. The one who was going to hand over the goods and then go back to my regular, slightly-less-pregnant life.

It was a weird dynamic, I'll admit. And Bren, being the fiercely protective, slightly-overbearing-but-ultimately-loving stepmom that she is, couldn't quite wrap her head around it. She saw a married man, a pregnant teenager, and probably envisioned a Lifetime movie plotline. I just saw two people who really wanted a baby, and me, the person who happened to have one cooking.

So, yeah, I probably brushed her off a bit. Made a joke. Changed the subject. Because sometimes, when people are worried about you, the best defense is a good offense of sarcasm and deflection. It's not that I didn't appreciate her concern, it's just… some things, you gotta figure out on your own, even if it means making a few people nervous along the way. And besides, it wasn't like I was *dating* Mark. That would have been a whole other level of messed up. This was… different. Complicated. And definitely not something you could explain in a soundbite to a worried stepmom.

Okay, first off, "Juno MacGuff, why did you pour your blue slushie into the urn?" sounds like something my mom would say, right before she grounded me for life. And honestly, it's a fair question.

The urn, right? The one in the waiting room at the abortion clinic. It was just... sitting there. All stoic and bronze and *empty*. And I had this blue raspberry slushie, which, let's be real, is basically liquid candy.

I guess it was a moment of pure, unadulterated, teenage rebellion. Or maybe just a really weird impulse. That whole day was just a blur of fluorescent lights and uncomfortable chairs and the kind of silence that screams louder than a rock concert. Everything felt so heavy, so *final*.

And then there was this urn, just begging for some kind of... disruption. Some kind of color. Some kind of *life*, even if it was just artificial blue raspberry life. It was like, "Hey, world, I'm here, and I'm not just going to sit here and be sad and quiet. I'm going to pour a slushie into an urn."

It was probably a little bit of a coping mechanism, too. A way to inject some absurdity into a situation that felt overwhelmingly serious. Like, "Okay, this is happening, but I can still be *me* in the middle of it." And "me" sometimes involves questionable decisions involving sugary drinks and decorative funeral paraphernalia.

Plus, it looked pretty cool, didn't it? That bright blue against the bronze? A little pop of unexpected. Like a tiny, sugary protest. Don't tell the clinic staff, though. They probably have enough on their plates without dealing with my artistic endeavors.

Coping? Man, that's a loaded word. It wasn't like I had a "Coping with Unexpected Pregnancy" handbook handed to me at the clinic. Mostly, I just… kept going. Like a really stubborn, slightly nauseous, human-shaped tumbleweed.

A lot of it was just trying to keep my head above water, you know? One minute I'm trying to figure out if I should go to college for graphic design or, like, professional napping, and the next I'm staring at a stick with two lines on it, and suddenly my biggest concern is whether or a not a baby can survive on a diet of SunnyD and sarcastic remarks. (Spoiler: probably not.)

The biggest thing, I guess, was just trying to maintain some semblance of normalcy. Which, let's be real, was a pretty futile effort. But I still went to school, still hung out with Leah, still tried to make snarky comments in class even when my brain felt like a deflated balloon. It was like, if I acted like everything was fine, maybe it would eventually *be* fine. Or at least, not completely catastrophic.

And then there was the whole adoption thing. That was a whole other beast. Trying to find the right people, trying to imagine a life for this kid that wasn't, you know, *my* life. That was heavy. But in a weird way, it also gave me a focus. It wasn't just about *me* anymore. It was about making a good decision for this tiny human who was currently using my bladder as a trampoline.

Honestly, a lot of it was just putting one foot in front of the other. And a healthy dose of dry humor. Because if you can't laugh at the absurdity of your own life, you're pretty much screwed, right? And having people like Paulie and Leah, even my dad and Brenda, who didn't treat me like I'd suddenly sprouted a second head, that helped. A lot. They just… let me be Juno, even when Juno was a walking, talking, pregnant question mark.

So, "coping"? It was messy. It was awkward. It was a lot of trying not to puke in public. But I got through it. And I guess, in the process, I figured out a few things about myself. Like, I'm tougher than I thought. And I'm actually pretty good at making decisions, even the really big, life-altering ones. Who knew?

Oh, Mark. Yeah, that was... an experience. Definitely not what I expected, which, let's be honest, is pretty much par for the course with this whole situation.

He was cool, you know? Like, *really* cool. Not in the "trying too hard" way, but in that effortless, indie-rock-dad-who-still-thinks-he's-in-a-band kind of way. His house was a shrine to all things awesome – records, movie posters, a whole room dedicated to his music. It was like stepping into a cooler, slightly more adult version of my own brain, if my brain had a mortgage and a penchant for obscure horror films.

We'd just... hang out. Watch movies, listen to music, talk about whatever. He treated me like a person, not like some walking incubator or a charity case. He actually listened when I talked about stuff, which, let's be real, is a rare commodity when you're a pregnant teenager. It was nice to just *be* for a bit, without the constant weight of the impending baby-bomb.

But then... well, then there was the whole "Vanessa" thing. And the fact that he was clearly still living in some kind of arrested development, clinging to his youth like a life raft. It was like he wanted to be a dad, but only the fun parts, the cool parts, the parts that didn't involve, you know, *actual responsibility*. And I get it, I really do. Who wants to grow up? But there's a difference between being young at heart and just... not growing up at all.

It was fun, though. For a while. Like a really good, slightly melancholic mixtape that you know has to end. It just made me realize that sometimes, the coolest people aren't always the most reliable. And that's a lesson I'm learning a lot of lately.

Oh, Bleeker. He's such a dork, but, like, *my* dork, you know? When he first started noticing... well, it was a mix of things.

Part of me wanted to just roll my eyes and tell him to get a grip. Like, "Yeah, Bleeker, it's not a food baby from too many Sunny D's, it's a *human being* in there. Shocking, I know." I mean, it's not exactly subtle, is it? It's kind of hard to miss when your midsection starts resembling a small, slightly deflated basketball.

But then there was this other part, this weird, squishy feeling. Like, even though it was *my* body and *my* situation, having him acknowledge it, in his own Bleeker-y, slightly awkward way, made it feel a little more... real, I guess. And less like I was just carrying around some alien parasite that only I could see. It was like, "Okay, someone else sees it. Someone else is in on this bizarre, life-altering secret."

And honestly? It was kind of sweet. In a totally non-sappy, Juno-approved way. He wasn't grossed out, he wasn't freaking out (at least not outwardly, the poor guy probably had internal freak-outs on the regular). He was just... observing. And that's Bleeker. He observes. And sometimes, that's exactly what you need. Someone to just *see* what's happening, without making a huge deal out of it, but still acknowledging it.

So, yeah. A little bit of "duh, Sherlock," a little bit of "oh, okay, he's still here," and a little bit of "huh, that's actually... nice." Don't tell him I said that last part, though. He'd probably spontaneously combust from the shock.
