Honestly? The most challenging part wasn't the morning sickness, or the weird cravings for SunnyD and Tic Tacs, or even the looks people gave me in the hallway like I was some kind of science experiment gone wrong.

It was the *decision*.

Not the decision to give the baby up, because, let's be real, I'm not exactly equipped to raise a human right now. My biggest responsibility before this was making sure my cat, Bleeker, didn't eat too much dry food.

No, the challenging part was the decision to *find* the right people. To sift through all those binders, those perfectly curated little lives, and try to figure out who would be the least likely to screw up this kid. It felt like I was playing God, but with way less experience and a lot more hormonal mood swings.

And then, once I found them, once I saw Mark and Vanessa's ad, it was like... okay, now what? Now I have to actually *meet* them. And pretend to be a normal, well-adjusted teenager who just happens to be carrying their future child. It's a lot of pressure, you know? To pick the perfect parents for a kid you haven't even met yet, a kid who's currently just doing the cha-cha slide on your bladder.

It's like trying to pick out the perfect pair of shoes for someone else, but you don't know their size, their style, or if they even *like* shoes. And the stakes are, like, infinitely higher. So yeah, the decision-making, the "who do I trust with this tiny human" part, that's been the real gut-punch.

Ugh, that guy. The one with the sign that looked like it was drawn by a particularly uninspired crayon. He was yelling something about how babies are, like, "gifts from God" and "precious miracles" and all that jazz. You know, the usual. Like I hadn't already considered that a tiny human was going to be, you know, *a human*.

He was also going on about how I'd regret it, how I'd be throwing away my "blessing." As if I was just casually tossing a half-eaten bag of chips in the trash, not making a decision that felt like it was going to rip my insides out and then put them back in a slightly different, more responsible order.

Honestly, it was just a lot of noise. Like a broken record playing the same three notes over and over. Didn't really offer any new insights into the whole "baby" situation, which, trust me, I'd been doing a lot of research on. More than he probably had, just standing there with his cardboard and his righteous indignation.

Alright, so picture this: I'm sitting there, in the clinic, feeling like a total alien in my own skin, right? And then this woman, she comes in. Not exactly what you'd call a ray of sunshine, more like a slightly deflated balloon. She had this whole "I've seen it all" vibe, you know?

She just kinda looked at me, like I was another statistic, another kid who made a dumb mistake. And then she hit me with the whole "Are you sure about this, honey?" routine. Like I hadn't been agonizing over it for, oh, I don't know, a lifetime and a half.

But then, she said something that actually kinda stuck. She said, "You're stronger than you think, and whatever you decide, it's *your* decision." And for some reason, coming from her, it didn't sound like a platitude. It sounded... real. Like she actually meant it. It was a weird moment, in a really weird day.

Oh, Su-Chin. That girl's got a radar for anything even remotely off-kilter, especially when it comes to, you know, *substances*. I just casually dropped the "Adderall" bomb, mostly to see what kind of ripple effect it would have in her perfectly organized, color-coded universe.

Her eyes, man, they got wide. Like, cartoonishly wide. And then she did this thing with her mouth, where it kind of puckered up like she'd just tasted something sour. She didn't even have to say anything, her face was a whole monologue. It was basically, "Juno MacGuff, are you *seriously* considering putting that kind of chemical into your body? Do you know the long-term effects? Have you consulted a medical professional? Is this a cry for help?" All without uttering a single syllable.

Then, of course, came the actual words, which were a more polite, Su-Chin-esque version of all that. Something about "potential side effects" and "alternative, holistic approaches to focus." She probably started mentally drafting a pamphlet on the dangers of prescription stimulants right then and there. It was pretty classic Su-Chin, honestly. Predictable, but still kind of amusing to watch. She means well, though. In her own, slightly alarmist way.

Okay, so, the waiting room. Not exactly a hotbed of thrilling entertainment, right? More like a purgatory of beige and bad magazines. But then, this one thing just… *grabbed* me.

It was this woman. She was sitting across from me, and she had this… *look*. Not sad, not angry, not even really scared, though I guess she had every right to be. It was more like… utterly, completely, irrevocably *empty*. Like someone had just scooped out her insides with a melon baller and left the shell.

And she was just staring at the wall. Not at anything specific, just *at* it. And her hands were clasped in her lap, so tight her knuckles were white. And I just kept thinking, "Is that what happens? Is that what this *does* to you?"

It wasn't the needles, or the doctors, or even the idea of the whole… *procedure*. It was *her*. That blankness. That's what made my stomach drop to my shoes and my throat feel like it was lined with sandpaper. Because for a second, I saw myself in that chair, looking just like her, and that was way more terrifying than any medical instrument.

Bleeker? Man, that's a loaded question, isn't it? Like, do I still have feelings for the guy who, you know, *fathered my child* and then stuck by me through the whole, intensely awkward, emotionally draining, and occasionally hilarious ordeal?

Yeah, I guess I do. Not in the "I wanna make out with him behind the bleachers and carve our initials into a tree" kind of way, not anymore. That's... that's a different kind of feeling. That's the kind of feeling you have for someone who saw you at your most vulnerable, your most confused, and your most hormonal, and still thought you were worth, like, bringing you a Slurpee and watching horror movies with.

He's a good egg, Bleeker. A little oblivious, maybe, and definitely obsessed with his track team, but he's got a good heart. And he was there. He was *really* there. So, yeah, I got feelings for him. They're just... grown-up feelings now, I guess. The kind that make you appreciate someone for who they are and what they did, even if you're not, like, planning your future together. It's a weird kind of love, maybe, but it's definitely there. Like a really comfortable, slightly worn-out hoodie. You know?

Okay, so, Vanessa's decorating choices for the baby's room, huh?

Look, I get it. She's excited. Like, *really* excited. And she's got this whole vision, which is, you know, *her* vision. And it's... very beige. And very... *tasteful*. Like, if "tasteful" was a color, it would be that exact shade of off-white she's got going on.

It's not exactly my vibe, you know? My vibe is more, I don't know, a little more punk rock, a little less Pottery Barn. I mean, where's the personality? Where's the, like, *edge*? It's all very... *serene*. Which, I guess, is good for a baby. Babies probably don't need a lot of edge. They're already pretty edgy just by existing and demanding things.

But, honestly? It's not about me. It's about her. And she loves it. She's got this whole nesting thing going on, and she's so genuinely happy about every little perfectly placed, probably organic, definitely expensive item. And seeing her like that, seeing her so completely invested and joyful... it's actually pretty cool.

So, yeah, if I were decorating, there'd probably be more band posters and less muted tones. But it's not my room, and it's not my baby, not in that way. It's *their* baby, and it's *her* room. And if it makes her happy, then it's perfect. Even if it does look like a page out of a very expensive, very quiet catalog.

Nesting? Huh. You know, I always pictured "nesting" as something, like, a robin does. Or maybe a particularly anxious squirrel. Not exactly my vibe, you know? My vibe is more... well, it's more like a slightly disheveled but ultimately functional badger sett. Or maybe a very organized dumpster.

As for preparing a baby's room... I mean, I get it. People do that. They paint little lambs on the walls and buy tiny, impractical shoes. And, like, good for them. Seriously. It's just... it's not really *my* baby's room, is it? Not in the way that, say, my room is *my* room, with its posters of The Stooges and the general aroma of stale pizza and existential dread.

I guess I've been more focused on, you know, the *actual* baby. The squishy, demanding, tiny human part. And the whole adoption thing. It's a lot to wrap your head around. So, while I appreciate the sentiment of a perfectly curated nursery, my brain's been a bit too busy trying to figure out how to, like, *not* screw up a human life to worry about the thread count of a crib sheet.

Plus, let's be real, if I tried to "nest," it would probably involve me just, like, aggressively organizing my comic book collection and maybe buying a new, slightly more comfortable beanbag chair. Not exactly the picture of domestic bliss, is it? More like the picture of a teenager trying to avoid responsibility by creating a fortress of pop culture. Which, honestly, is pretty accurate.

Oh, the mall. Yeah, that was... an experience. You know, I'm not exactly a connoisseur of high fashion or anything, but even I could tell these women were operating on a whole different plane of existence.

It was like a safari, but instead of gazelles, you had these perfectly coiffed, designer-clad ladies, all with that same kind of glazed-over, slightly bored look in their eyes. Like they'd seen it all, bought it all, and were just waiting for the next shipment of whatever ridiculously priced bauble was going to momentarily fill the void.

And the way they shopped! It wasn't about *needing* something, or even really *wanting* something in the way a normal person wants a new pair of sneakers. It was more like a ritual. They'd glide into a store, barely glance at the price tags – because, let's be real, those numbers were probably just decorative to them – and then just... acquire. Like they were collecting trophies for their perfectly curated lives.

The sales associates, bless their hearts, were practically bowing and scraping. "Oh, Mrs. So-and-So, this new cashmere blend just arrived, it would look *divine* on you." And Mrs. So-and-So would just nod, maybe offer a faint, almost imperceptible smile, and then point to a rack of clothes that probably cost more than my dad's car.

It was just so... *effortless* for them. Like money was just this endless, flowing river they could dip their hands into whenever they felt a slight tremor of dissatisfaction. And I'm standing there, trying to figure out if I have enough change for a Slurpee, watching them drop a grand on a scarf. It was a little surreal, to be honest. A whole different ecosystem. Made me feel like I'd stumbled into a nature documentary about a species I didn't quite understand.

Motherhood? Ha. That's a loaded word, isn't it? Like a really big, lumpy, uncomfortable beanbag chair that you're suddenly expected to sit in for the rest of your life.

Honestly, the "changes" are already happening, and they're not exactly subtle. My body's doing all sorts of weird, alien things, and my brain feels like it's been rewired to constantly think about... well, *it*. The little blueberry. The tiny human. It's like having a permanent, internal alarm clock that just keeps ticking, reminding you that there's a whole other person in there, demanding attention.

As for "responsibilities"... that's the real kicker, isn't it? I mean, I'm barely responsible for keeping my own socks matched, let alone a whole other human being. The idea of being solely responsible for someone's entire existence, their well-being, their future... it's like trying to juggle flaming chainsaws while riding a unicycle on a tightrope. Terrifying. Absolutely terrifying.

That's why... well, that's why I'm doing what I'm doing. Because I know, deep down in my gut, that I'm not ready for *that* kind of responsibility. Not yet. Maybe not ever, in the traditional sense. But I can be responsible enough to make sure this little blueberry gets the best shot at life, even if that shot isn't with me. It's a different kind of responsibility, I guess. A more... strategic one. Less about changing diapers and more about changing destinies.

It's a lot to chew on, you know? It's like being handed a really complicated Rubik's Cube and being told to solve it before the timer runs out. And the timer is, like, nine months. So, yeah. "Changes and responsibilities." They're definitely here. And they're definitely making my head spin. But I'm trying to keep my wits about me. Mostly.

Alright, so, "specific type of person," huh? It's not like I'm drawing up a blueprint for a perfect human or anything. More like... I'm looking for a *good* fit. You know, someone who's actually *ready* for this whole baby thing. Because, let's be real, I'm not. Not even close.

I mean, I'm still trying to figure out if I should go to college or just become a professional napper. How am I supposed to raise a tiny human when I can barely keep my own socks matched?

So, yeah, I'm looking for people who seem like they've got their act together. People who actually *want* this, not just because it's what you're "supposed" to do. People who have a house that doesn't smell like stale pizza and regret. People who seem like they could actually teach a kid something useful, like how to ride a bike without breaking a limb, or how to appreciate a good horror movie.

And, honestly, I'm looking for people who seem like they'd be *happy* about it. Like, genuinely thrilled. Because this kid deserves that. They deserve to be wanted, to be loved, to be the center of someone's universe. And right now, my universe is mostly centered around trying to avoid awkward conversations in the school hallway.

It's not about being picky, it's about being responsible. Or, as responsible as a pregnant teenager can be, anyway. I'm just trying to do right by this little bean, even if it means making a decision that feels like it's going to rip my guts out. But, you know, in a good way. A responsible, gut-wrenching way.

Woah, hold your horses there, chief. "If I decide to keep the baby"? That's a pretty big "if," isn't it? Like, a Grand Canyon-sized "if." But since you asked, and since my brain is currently a superhighway of "what ifs," let's just say the list of concerns is longer than a CVS receipt.

First off, there's the whole "being a parent" thing. I'm seventeen. My biggest responsibility right now is making sure my cat, Bleeker, doesn't eat too much dry food and get a hairball on my dad's favorite armchair. I can barely keep a houseplant alive, let alone a tiny, squishy human who needs, like, constant attention and food and diaper changes. I'm pretty sure I'd accidentally put its onesie on backward for the first six months.

Then there's the money. Or, more accurately, the distinct lack thereof. Babies, apparently, are not cheap. Like, at all. Diapers, formula, clothes they outgrow in five minutes, a crib, a stroller... I'm pretty sure the cost of a baby could buy me a lifetime supply of SunnyD and a really sweet vintage record player. My current income consists of babysitting for the occasional desperate neighbor and whatever loose change I find under the couch cushions. Not exactly a robust financial plan for a new family.

And school? Forget about it. I'm trying to graduate, you know? Get into college, maybe study something cool like... I don't know, film or something. How am I supposed to do that with a crying infant strapped to my chest during calculus? I'd be the weird pregnant girl who smells faintly of spit-up and exhaustion. Not exactly the "cool, quirky indie kid" vibe I'm going for.

Then there's the social aspect. My friends are all talking about prom and college applications and who's hooking up with whom. I'd be talking about colic and sleep deprivation. It's a pretty stark contrast. And let's not even get started on the looks. The judgment. The whispers. "Oh, look, it's Juno MacGuff, the teenage mom." Like it's some kind of scarlet letter.

And finally, there's the biggest obstacle of all: me. Am I even capable of being a good mom? I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I'm still trying to navigate the labyrinth that is high school and growing up. How can I guide another human being through life when I'm still tripping over my own two feet? It's a lot to think about, you know? A whole lot. And frankly, it's enough to make my brain feel like a scrambled egg.

Alright, so I'm sitting there, right? My brain's doing this whole pretzel thing trying to figure out how to un-pregnant myself, and the adoption idea just kinda… popped out. Like a really ungraceful, slightly terrifying thought bubble.

And Leah, bless her cotton socks, she's trying to be supportive, but also, you know, *Leah*. She's got this whole "let's explore all the avenues, even the ones that make your uterus clench" vibe going on.

So when I floated the adoption thing, she didn't exactly jump for joy. Her big alternative, her brilliant stroke of genius, was basically: "What about keeping it?"

Yeah. "What about keeping it?" Like it was a stray kitten I found in a dumpster and not, you know, a whole human being that was currently using my bladder as a trampoline. She started talking about how we could totally do it, how she'd help, how it wouldn't be *that* bad. Like we'd just add a tiny, screaming, pooping roommate to our already chaotic lives.

I mean, I love Leah, but sometimes her optimism is so blinding it makes me want to wear sunglasses indoors. Keeping it? Me? Juno MacGuff, the queen of questionable life choices and even more questionable fashion? Raising a baby? That's like asking a squirrel to perform open-heart surgery. It just doesn't compute.

So yeah, her big alternative was the one that made my ovaries shrivel up and hide. Good intentions, terrible execution. That's Leah for you.

Alright, look, "make fun of" is a bit of a strong phrase, don't you think? It's not like I was actively trying to be a jerk. More like... observing. With a healthy dose of internal monologue, maybe.

But if you're really asking *why* my brain went there, it's because... well, it was a lot. All those moms, with their matching yoga pants and their organic juice boxes, and their perfectly coiffed hair, all talking about their kids' bowel movements like it was the most fascinating topic on the planet. And the way they were all just... *there*. So settled. So *mom-like*.

It was just so far removed from anything I was experiencing, or even *could* experience at that point. I was this giant, pregnant, awkward alien in their perfectly curated universe. And sometimes, when you feel like an outsider, your brain just defaults to a little bit of snark as a defense mechanism. It's easier to make a joke than to feel completely overwhelmed and out of place, you know?

Plus, let's be real, some of those conversations *were* pretty ripe for a little internal commentary. I'm just saying.

Woah, deep question there, huh? Like, "Why did the chicken cross the road?" but with more... uterine implications.

Honestly, it wasn't some grand, philosophical decision, you know? It was just... a moment. Vanessa, she's got this whole vibe, this quiet intensity. And she'd been so *there* for everything, in her own way. Not in a gushy, "Oh my god, a baby!" kind of way, but in a solid, reliable, "I'm here if you need me to drive you to a doctor's appointment at 7 AM" kind of way.

And when she asked... it wasn't a demand. It was more like a hopeful whisper. And I looked at her, and I saw this... longing. This genuine, unadulterated desire to connect with this little bean that was doing the cha-cha in my insides.

It wasn't *my* belly, not really. Not in the way it was *mine* before. It was becoming *ours*, in a weird, complicated, adoption-agreement kind of way. And in that moment, it just felt right. Like a silent acknowledgment of what we were all doing, what we were all in together. A little bit of a peace offering, maybe. A way to say, "Yeah, this is happening. And you're a part of it."

Plus, she looked like she was gonna spontaneously combust if I said no. And who wants that on their conscience? Not me, MacGuff. Not me.

Huh. You know, I hadn't really thought about it like that. I guess it's not like I'm *trying* to part the Red Sea with my uterus or anything. But you're right, there's definitely a shift.

Maybe it's the whole "fragile cargo" thing. Like, suddenly I'm not just some sarcastic teenager with a penchant for orange soda, I'm a walking, talking incubator. And people, for all their flaws, generally have this weird, primal respect for that. It's like, "Oh, look, a future human! Better not bump into that."

Or maybe it's just the sheer *awkwardness* of it. I mean, I'm not exactly graceful these days. I waddle. I bump into things. My center of gravity is completely off-kilter. So maybe they're just trying to avoid a collision with a giant, pregnant bowling ball. Self-preservation, you know?

And then there's the whole "sympathy" angle. Like, "Poor kid, she's got a watermelon strapped to her front, let's give her some space." Which, honestly, is a little patronizing, but I'll take the extra elbow room.

Mostly, I think it's just that people don't really know what to *do* with a pregnant teenager. It's not exactly a common sight in the hallways of my high school. So they just... default to giving way. It's easier than making eye contact, I guess. Less chance of having to actually *talk* to the girl with the belly. And honestly, sometimes I appreciate that. My social battery is already running on fumes these days.

"Wholesome." Yeah, that's the word they used. Like a bag of organic kale chips or something. And don't get me wrong, I'm all for kale chips in theory, but sometimes you just want a greasy, questionable taco, you know?

It's not that I think they're *bad* people. They're... nice. Almost *too* nice. Like they stepped out of a Pottery Barn catalog, all perfectly coordinated and smelling faintly of lavender. And the house? Immaculate. Like a museum where you're afraid to touch anything.

I guess it's just... I'm not exactly a Pottery Barn kind of person. My life's a little more... thrift store chic, with a side of questionable stains. And I keep thinking, what if this kid ends up being like me? What if they're a little weird, a little sarcastic, a little... *unwholesome*? Will they fit in there? Will they be happy?

It's not about them, really. It's about me, projecting all my own anxieties onto this whole situation. I just want to make sure this kid gets a good shot, and "wholesome" just feels a little... restrictive, maybe? Like they'll have to live up to some kind of perfect ideal, and who wants that kind of pressure? I mean, I barely manage to tie my own shoes most days.

Plus, the whole "we're going to paint the nursery yellow because it's a happy color" thing. I mean, who *decides* that? What if the kid hates yellow? What if they're more of a deep, brooding indigo kind of person? Just sayin'. It's a lot to think about.

Okay, Mark and Vanessa Loring. That's a loaded question, isn't it?

Vanessa... she's, well, she's *Vanessa*. She's got this whole perfectly put-together thing going on, like she stepped out of a Pottery Barn catalog. A little intense, maybe, with the whole "baby room" thing, but you can tell she's got a good heart. She really, *really* wants this. Like, more than anyone I've ever met wants anything. And that's... admirable, I guess. A little scary, too, because it's such a huge responsibility, you know? But she's got that maternal glow, even without the actual baby yet. She's gonna be a good mom. A really, really good mom.

Mark... Mark's a different story. He's cool, you know? Like, genuinely cool. He's got all the records, the movie posters, the witty banter. We clicked, definitely. We could talk about horror movies and music for hours. It was easy. Maybe a little *too* easy, in a way. He's still kind of a kid himself, even though he's, like, a grown-up. And that's where it gets tricky. He's got this whole Peter Pan vibe, and I get it, I really do. Who wants to grow up and deal with all the boring adult stuff? But when you're talking about bringing a whole new human into the world, "Peter Pan" isn't exactly the most reassuring job title.

So, how do I feel? It's complicated. Vanessa, I respect her. I think she's going to be an amazing mother, and that's what matters most. Mark... I like him. A lot. But I also see that he's not quite ready for the whole "dad" thing, not in the way Vanessa is ready for "mom." And that's a tough pill to swallow when you're trying to make the best decision for a tiny, innocent person. It's like, you want them to be a unit, a team, but sometimes life just doesn't work out that way, does it?

Oh, Bleeker's mom. Mrs. Bleeker. The woman who looks at me like I'm a particularly virulent strain of head lice.

Honestly, I think it's a whole cocktail of reasons, shaken not stirred, with a twist of "my son is too good for *that*."

First off, I'm pretty sure she thinks I'm a bad influence. Like, I'm going to drag Bleeker down into a life of... I don't know, indie rock concerts and sarcastic remarks. She probably envisions me leading him astray, away from his track practice and his perfectly ironed shirts. I'm not exactly the picture of a demure, polite, future-daughter-in-law, am I? My fashion sense leans more towards "thrift store chic" than "country club casual."

Then there's the whole "unexpected pregnancy" thing. That probably didn't exactly endear me to her. I mean, I get it. It's not exactly the ideal scenario for your son's girlfriend. But it's not like I *planned* it. And Bleeker's been... well, Bleeker's been Bleeker. He's been solid. But I'm sure she sees me as the one who "got him into trouble."

And let's be real, I'm not exactly a social butterfly when it comes to adults. I'm more of a sarcastic caterpillar. I don't really do the whole "charming small talk" thing. I'm pretty sure my attempts at politeness come off as either awkward or vaguely threatening. So, yeah, I probably haven't won her over with my sparkling personality.

Mostly, I think she just sees me as... different. And not in a good way. She probably wants someone who fits neatly into her idea of what a girlfriend for her son should be. Someone who's more... conventional. More predictable. And I'm about as predictable as a rogue squirrel with a caffeine addiction.

So, yeah. It's not exactly a love connection between me and Mrs. Bleeker. But hey, at least Bleeker still likes me. That's the important part, right?

Honestly? At first, it was probably just because it was *there*. Like, a physical object in a world full of digital noise. Mark had this whole thing about music, you know? He wasn't just *listening* to it, he was *experiencing* it, dissecting it. And he was always trying to get me to see the light, to appreciate the "real" stuff.

So, he made me this CD. And I probably rolled my eyes, because that's just what I do. But then, there's this weird, quiet moment, and you're just... bored. Or maybe you're trying to avoid thinking about something else. And there's this CD, sitting there, all shiny and full of potential.

I think I put it on mostly out of curiosity, and maybe a little bit to shut him up about it. But then... then it just *clicked*. It wasn't just a bunch of songs. It was *his* taste, curated, a little window into his brain. And some of those bands, man, they just hit different. It was like finding a secret language I didn't know I was missing.

So yeah, started out of convenience, maybe a little bit of obligation, but then it became something else entirely. It became *mine*, too.

Alright, so you wanna know how it feels to be a walking, talking, human-sized watermelon, huh? Well, let me tell ya, it's a real trip.

First off, the whole "glowing" thing? Total myth. Unless "glowing" means perpetually sweating and looking like I just ran a marathon in a sauna. My feet are officially the size of small canoes, and finding shoes that don't make me feel like I'm trying to squeeze a couple of grapefruits into thimbles is a daily Olympic sport.

And the bladder situation? Don't even get me started. I'm pretty sure my internal organs have decided to play a game of musical chairs, and my bladder always loses. Every five minutes, it's like, "Surprise! Time for another pit stop!" I'm practically best friends with every public restroom in a ten-mile radius.

Then there's the whole "baby moving" thing. At first, it was kinda cool, like a little alien doing a soft shoe shuffle in there. Now? It's more like a full-on mosh pit. I swear, sometimes it feels like it's trying to kick its way out, like a tiny, impatient escape artist. My ribs are taking a beating, and I'm pretty sure my internal organs are just along for the ride, hoping for the best.

Sleep? What's sleep? I spend half the night trying to find a position that doesn't feel like I'm being crushed by a small boulder, and the other half getting up to pee. It's like my body has decided to prepare me for the sleep deprivation of a newborn by giving me a head start. Thanks, body. Real helpful.

But, you know, despite all the aches and the waddling and the constant need to pee, there's this weird, kinda profound thing happening too. Like, this little person is in there, getting ready to, you know, *be* a person. And even though it's not gonna be *my* person in the traditional sense, it's still... something. It's a lot to wrap your head around, even for a seasoned cynic like myself.

So, yeah. Almost eight months. It's a lot. It's uncomfortable. It's kinda gross. But it's also... something else. Something big. And I'm just trying to keep my head above water, one giant, swollen foot at a time.

Honestly? Probably because I look like I just rolled out of bed and then got into a fight with a thrift store. Or maybe it's the giant, ever-expanding basketball under my shirt. That tends to draw a few eyeballs.

But, like, beyond the obvious, I think people just aren't used to seeing someone who doesn't really give a crap what they think. I'm not exactly blending in with the pastel-wearing, perfectly coiffed crowd, am I? I'm just... me. And sometimes "me" is a little too much for some people to process. It's like they're trying to figure out if I'm a walking art project or just really, really bad at fashion.

Mostly, though, I just assume they're wondering if I'm going to spontaneously combust or say something incredibly inappropriate. Which, let's be real, is always a distinct possibility. Keeps life interesting, right?

Bleek and Katrina De Voort, huh? That's... a concept. Like, a really, really *conceptual* concept.

On the one hand, Bleek's a good guy. He deserves to go to prom with someone who makes him happy, someone who's not, you know, *me* and all my current... *situations*. And Katrina, she's... well, she's Katrina. She's got that whole cheerleader, perfectly coiffed, "I probably have a Pinterest board dedicated to prom themes" vibe. She's probably got a dress picked out since freshman year.

So, from a purely logistical, "everyone deserves a prom date" standpoint, sure. Why not? It's a classic pairing, like peanut butter and... well, not *my* kind of jelly, but someone else's kind of jelly.

But then, there's the other hand. The hand that remembers Bleek and me, and how things were. And Katrina... she's just so *different*. So polished. So... *normal*. Bleek's not exactly a normal guy, not really. He's got that quiet intensity, that way of looking at you like he's actually *seeing* you. I just wonder if Katrina would actually *see* him, or just see the idea of him, the football player, the prom date.

It's not my business, really. My business is... well, it's a whole other kind of business right now. But if Bleek's happy, then I guess that's what matters. Even if it means him slow-dancing with someone who probably smells like a flower shop and has perfect posture. Just... try not to think about it too much, you know? It's just prom. It's not like it's forever. Or is it? Ugh. Never mind.

Woah, that's a loaded question, even for me. I mean, before all this, I thought I had myself pretty much figured out. You know, the sarcastic, slightly-too-smart-for-my-own-good, indie-rock-loving Juno. Turns out, there's a whole lot more under the surface than just a killer playlist and a penchant for orange soda.

First off, I learned I'm way tougher than I gave myself credit for. Like, seriously. I thought I'd crumble, or at least spend nine months in a fetal position, crying into a bag of Cheetos. But I didn't. I mean, yeah, there were moments, but I kept going. I made a decision, and I stuck with it, even when it felt like the whole world was looking at me like I had two heads.

And then there's the whole "vulnerability" thing. Blech. I used to think that was for, like, people in rom-coms. But when you're carrying a whole human inside you, and you're trying to figure out what the hell you're going to do with it, you kinda have to let your guard down. I actually talked to people. Like, *really* talked. My dad, my stepmom, even Bleeker. And it turns out, they're not just there to make snarky comments about my life choices. They actually... care. Who knew?

I also learned that I'm not just some kid floating through life. I can make big decisions. Important ones. And I can follow through. It's not just about me anymore, and that's a pretty heavy realization. It's like, suddenly, the universe decided to hand me a giant, squishy, incredibly important responsibility, and I actually rose to the occasion.

So, yeah. I'm still Juno. Still got the snark, still got the orange soda. But now, I'm also Juno who knows she can handle a lot more than she ever thought possible. And that's... kinda cool, I guess. In a totally non-sappy, Juno-approved way.

Look, it's not like I'm suddenly the president of the Bleeker-Katrina fan club or anything. And honestly, Bleeker's a good kid, a little... *Bleeker*, but good. But Katrina? She's not exactly a hardened veteran of the emotional battlefield, you know? She's got this whole delicate, artsy vibe going on, and she's pretty sweet.

I just don't want to see her get all tangled up and hurt. Bleeker's got this way of being oblivious, and sometimes that obliviousness can come across as, well, *toying*. He's probably not even doing it on purpose, but that doesn't make it any less sucky for the person on the receiving end.

It's just... I've seen enough people get their hearts stomped on, and it's never a pretty sight. Especially when it's someone who doesn't deserve it. So yeah, I'm a little concerned. Is that so weird? I mean, I'm not a total monster. Most of the time.

Alright, so you wanna know why prom, that supposed pinnacle of high school glory, loses its luster once you're actually, you know, *eligible*? It's a classic bait-and-switch, my friend.

See, when you're a little kid, or even a freshman, prom is this mythical beast. It's all about the fancy dresses, the limos, the *romance* of it all. It's what the movies tell you it is. It's the ultimate "happily ever after" for a high schooler.

But then you get there. You're old enough. And suddenly, it's not this magical, ethereal event. It's just... another school dance. But with more expensive, uncomfortable shoes and the added pressure of pretending you're having the time of your life while your feet are screaming and the DJ is playing some god-awful remix of a song that was already bad to begin with.

It's like when you finally get to eat that super-hyped candy bar you've been seeing commercials for your whole life, and it just tastes like... sugar. And disappointment.

The *idea* of prom is way cooler than the reality. The anticipation is the best part. Once you're old enough, you realize it's just a bunch of people trying too hard, spending too much money, and probably getting into some kind of drama in the parking lot. It's the last gasp of forced fun before you're unleashed into the real world, where you can actually choose who you hang out with and what kind of music you listen to.

So, yeah. The magic wears off because you realize it was never really magic to begin with. It was just a really good marketing campaign. And once you're old enough, you're too smart for that. Or at least, you *should* be.

Alright, so, the whole adoption thing. It wasn't exactly a spur-of-the-moment, "ooh, shiny!" kind of decision, you know? More like a slow-burn realization, like when you're trying to figure out if that weird smell in the fridge is actually *you* or just some forgotten science experiment.

Initially, when I found out... well, let's just say my first thought wasn't "time to knit tiny booties!" It was more like, "holy *crap*, what now?" I mean, I'm sixteen. My biggest responsibility before this was making sure my cat, Bleeker, didn't eat the houseplants. And even *that* was a struggle.

I considered the other option, obviously. But the thought of being a mom, like, *really* being a mom, right now? It felt like trying to pilot a jumbo jet after only ever riding a unicycle. I'd probably crash and burn, and take a tiny, innocent passenger down with me. And that just didn't seem fair. To anyone.

Then there was the whole "what kind of life could I give this kid?" question. I'm still figuring out my own life, you know? My biggest aspiration is to maybe, someday, not have to ask my dad for gas money. Not exactly a solid foundation for raising a human being. I wanted this kid to have, like, a *good* life. A life where they weren't constantly wondering if their mom was going to accidentally set the kitchen on fire while trying to make toast.

So, adoption. It just... clicked. It felt like the most responsible, least selfish thing I could do. It wasn't about *me* not wanting a baby, it was about *the baby* deserving more than I could give it right then. It was about finding people who were ready, who actually *wanted* to do the whole parent thing, and who could give this kid a life that was, you know, *better* than what I could offer.

It's not an easy choice, don't get me wrong. There are moments when you feel like a total weirdo, like you're doing something completely against the grain. But then you remember why you're doing it, and it makes sense. It's like, sometimes the bravest thing you can do is admit you're not ready for something, and then find someone who is. And that's what I did.

(Sighs, a slight roll of the eyes, but a hint of a smile plays on her lips.)

Oh, my dad. Bless his overprotective, slightly paranoid heart. Honestly, it's classic MacGuff. He means well, you know? He just sees the world as this giant, predatory beast waiting to pounce on his little, pregnant, slightly-too-clever-for-her-own-good daughter.

Part of me gets it. I mean, it's a pretty big deal, right? Handing over a kid. And there are definitely some shady characters out there, I'm sure. But the whole "getting ripped off" thing... it's not like I'm selling a used car, you know? It's a baby. And I'm not exactly looking for a profit margin here.

Mostly, I think he's just scared. Scared for me, scared for the baby, scared of the whole situation. And when my dad gets scared, he gets all... *vigilante*. He wants to make sure I'm not getting taken advantage of, that I'm making the right choices, that I'm not going to end up crying into a pint of Ben & Jerry's while some slick adoption agent drives off in a new Mercedes.

It's sweet, in a very MacGuff-ian, slightly-embarrassing way. But I've got a pretty good radar for BS, and I'm not exactly a wilting flower. I'm doing my homework, asking the tough questions, and I'm not going to let anyone pull the wool over my eyes. Besides, I've got a pretty good feeling about these two. They seem... decent. In their own slightly-too-perfect, Pottery Barn kind of way.

So, yeah, Dad's concern is there. It's a constant, low hum in the background. But I'm pretty sure I've got this. And if I don't, well, I know he'll be there with his baseball bat and a very stern lecture. Which, honestly, is kind of comforting in its own weird way.

(A slight, almost imperceptible smirk plays on my lips, a familiar defense mechanism kicking in.)

Oh, *that* comment. Yeah, well, my dad's got a knack for stating the obvious, doesn't he? Like, "Juno, the sky is blue," or "Juno, you're currently breathing." It's not exactly groundbreaking news, is it?

Honestly, it's just... Dad. He means well, I guess. In his own gruff, slightly bewildered way. He's probably just trying to wrap his head around the whole situation, and "not knowing when to say when" is his shorthand for "holy crap, my teenage daughter is pregnant and I have no idea what's going on."

And, you know, maybe there's a kernel of truth in it. I tend to dive headfirst into things, sometimes without looking. It's not always a bad thing, though. Sometimes you gotta just *go* for it, right? Otherwise, you just sit around wondering "what if." And "what if" is a pretty lame place to live.

But yeah, "not knowing when to say when." It's a classic MacGuff-ism. Comes with the territory, I guess. (I shrug, a little too casually.) What's he gonna say next, that I don't know how to tie my shoes? Please. I'm practically a pro at that.

Alright, the Loring's gated community, huh? Well, it's... *something*.

On the one hand, it's like stepping into a whole other dimension. Everything's so perfectly manicured, you could probably eat off the lawns. And the houses? They're like something out of a magazine, all pristine and, you know, *tasteful*. It's got that whole "we've made it" vibe, where everyone's got their own little slice of suburban paradise, complete with the perfectly symmetrical shrubbery and the quiet hum of central air conditioning. It's definitely a far cry from my place, where the biggest landscaping project is usually just trying to keep the weeds from taking over the driveway.

But then, there's the *gated* part. It's like, what are they keeping out? Or in? It feels a little... sterile, you know? Like everything's been carefully curated to keep out anything remotely messy or unpredictable. It's almost *too* perfect, to the point where it feels a little suffocating. Like, where do you even put a slightly crooked garden gnome without upsetting the delicate balance of the universe?

And the people... they're nice, don't get me wrong. Mark and Vanessa are, you know, *good people*. But there's this underlying sense of... *performance* to it all. Like everyone's playing a role in this perfect little suburban drama. It's not exactly my scene, with all its unspoken rules and its perfectly paved paths. I'm more of a "find your own way through the overgrown weeds" kind of girl.

So, yeah, it's fancy. It's impressive. But it's also a little bit like visiting a really well-designed museum exhibit. You can appreciate the artistry, but you wouldn't necessarily want to live inside it. Give me a little grit, a little chaos, a little bit of real life, and I'm a lot more comfortable.

Okay, so Vanessa Loring. My initial impressions? Well, let's just say she wasn't exactly what I pictured when I thought "prospective adoptive mother."

First off, she was *intense*. Not in a bad way, necessarily, but like, every fiber of her being was screaming "I want a baby!" It was almost palpable, you know? Like she had this invisible neon sign flashing above her head. And she was so... *perfect*. Her house was perfect, her clothes were perfect, her hair was perfect. It was like stepping into a magazine spread, and I'm more of a crumpled-up comic book kind of girl.

She was also a little... stiff. Like she was trying really hard to be cool and casual, but it just came off as a bit rehearsed. Like she'd read a "How to Talk to Pregnant Teenagers" manual and was trying to implement all the bullet points. Which, I get it, it's a weird situation for everyone. But it made me feel a little like a science experiment, or a particularly delicate piece of pottery she was afraid of breaking.

But, and this is a big "but," there was something really genuine under all that. You could tell she was just *aching* to be a mom. And even though she was a little awkward, she was also really sweet. Like, she brought me those little orange Tic Tacs, which was a weirdly specific and thoughtful gesture. And she listened, really listened, even when I was probably rambling about something totally irrelevant.

So, yeah, initial impressions: a little overwhelming, a little too perfect, but with this undeniable, almost heartbreaking, desire to be a mother. It was a lot to take in, especially when you're just trying to figure out if you're going to barf in her perfectly manicured living room.

(A slight smirk plays on my lips, a familiar glint in my eye as I recall the moment.)

Bleeker, huh? Yeah, that kid. He's got a way of… well, being Bleeker.

When he offered to carry my backpack, it was classic Bleeker. Like, the kind of gesture that's so genuinely *him* it almost makes you roll your eyes, but then you don't, because it's also kind of sweet.

Honestly? My first thought was probably something along the lines of, "Oh, for crying out loud, Bleeker, you don't have to." Because, you know, I'm Juno. I can carry my own damn backpack. I've been carrying my own damn backpack since I was old enough to walk. It's not like I'm some delicate flower who's going to wilt under the weight of a few textbooks and a half-eaten granola bar.

But then… then there's that other part. The part that knows Bleeker. He wasn't doing it to be patronizing or anything. He was just… being helpful. Being *Bleeker*. And sometimes, even when you're Juno MacGuff and you've got everything under control, it's nice to have someone offer. It's a small thing, but it's a *thing*.

So, yeah, I probably gave him some sarcastic retort, because that's my default setting. But deep down? It was… fine. It was Bleeker. And sometimes, Bleeker's just what you need, even if you don't realize it until he's already doing it. He's got a knack for that.

Alright, so, "Most Fruitful Yuki," right? That comic. It's not like it magically transformed me into a supermodel or anything. I still had my questionable fashion choices and my general air of being a walking, talking sarcasm dispenser.

But, you know, there's something about seeing someone else's messed-up, awkward, totally unglamorous life laid out in panels. Yuki, she's not exactly the picture of perfection, is she? She's got her own weird hang-ups and her own brand of dorkiness. And she's still, like, the protagonist of her own story. She's still *doing* things.

It's like... when you're feeling like a fat dork, you tend to think you're the *only* fat dork. Or at least, the *most* fat dork. And then you read something like "Most Fruitful Yuki," and you realize, "Oh. Right. There are other people out there who are just as, if not more, spectacularly uncool than I am." And they're still, you know, existing. And sometimes, even thriving in their own weird way.

It's not about suddenly feeling *cool*. It's about feeling a little less *alone* in the uncoolness. It's like a tiny, almost imperceptible shift in the universe where you realize your particular brand of awkward isn't a cosmic anomaly, but just... a brand. And maybe, just maybe, that's okay. It's a small comfort, but sometimes, a small comfort is all you need to keep from completely spiraling into a black hole of self-pity and bad hair days.

(A slight smirk plays on my lips, a familiar glint in my eye as I recall the conversation with Mark. I lean back a little, crossing my arms, considering the question.)

Well, I mean, it's not exactly rocket science, is it? He's got this whole collection of comic books, right? And he's trying to, like, *relate* to my current... predicament. And what's more relatable than a pregnant superhero?

Honestly, I think it was his way of trying to make me feel, I don't know, *less* like a giant, walking science experiment and *more* like... well, like a superhero. Which, let's be real, is a pretty tall order when you're lugging around a watermelon-sized human.

Plus, you know, Mark's a pretty cool dude. He's got that whole indie rock, graphic novel vibe going on. So for him to compare me to something out of his world, something he clearly thinks is awesome, it's kind of a compliment, I guess. Even if the idea of me in a cape, fighting crime with a baby bump, is pretty hilarious. I'd probably just trip over my own feet.

But yeah, I think he was just trying to be supportive, in his own Mark-esque, comic-book-nerd kind of way. And maybe, just maybe, he saw a little bit of that "super" in me. Or at least, the "hero" part for not completely freaking out. Yet.

Alright, so, open adoption. It's like, a whole thing, right? People talk about it like it's the new, enlightened way to do things. And I get it, I really do. The idea of the kid knowing where they came from, having access to their birth parents, all that jazz. On paper, it sounds pretty… progressive. Like something a really well-adjusted, emotionally mature adult would choose.

But for me? Nah. Not my jam.

When I first started looking into this whole adoption thing, my brain was already doing backflips. I was trying to figure out how to be a person, let alone a person who was about to have a person. And the thought of having this… ongoing relationship? With the kid, with the adoptive parents, with *me*? It just felt like a recipe for a whole lot of awkwardness and confusion.

I mean, imagine it. The kid's growing up, and suddenly there's this other set of people, me, floating around. What's my role? Am I like, a cool aunt? A weird, biological ghost? And what about the adoptive parents? They're the ones doing the heavy lifting, the late-night feedings, the scraped knees, the college applications. They're the parents. And I just… pop in for a visit? It feels like it could muddy the waters, you know? Like, who's *really* the mom?

And honestly, for me, a big part of this decision was about giving this kid a clean slate. A chance to just be a kid, with a family that chose them, without the baggage of my own teenage screw-up hanging over their head. I wanted them to have a normal, uncomplicated life. And for me, that meant stepping back. Letting them have their own story, with their own parents, without me being a footnote in every chapter.

It's not that I don't care. Believe me, I care more than I've ever cared about anything. But sometimes, caring means knowing when to let go. And for me, a traditional closed adoption felt like the most responsible, the most loving way to do that. It's about giving them a clear path, not a tangled one. It's about them having a family, not two half-families. It's about them being whole, and me being okay with that. Even if it means I'm not in the picture.

Woah, deep. You're not wrong though. Before all this... *gestures vaguely at my belly, then at the world*... I was just... Juno. You know? The sarcastic one, the one who always had a comeback, the one who could out-snark anyone. And yeah, that's still me, obviously. You don't just shed your entire personality like a snake sheds its skin.

But before, it felt like that was *all* I was. Like the sarcasm was a shield, and if I ever dropped it, I'd just... dissolve. Or get eaten by a bear. Probably a metaphorical bear, but still.

Then, boom. Two lines on a stick. And suddenly, the shield felt a lot heavier. And a lot less effective. Because no amount of witty banter was gonna make this go away.

The strength, I think, came from having to actually *decide*. Not just react, not just make a joke, but actually sit with something huge and terrifying and figure out what *I* was going to do. And then, even harder, actually *do* it. Going to the clinic, talking to Leah, telling my parents, meeting the Loringers... every single one of those was like lifting a really heavy weight. And I didn't always do it gracefully, believe me. There were tears, there was yelling, there was a lot of orange soda.

But with each step, I realized I *could* do it. I wasn't just the girl who could talk a good game; I was the girl who could actually *do* a good game. Or, you know, a really complicated, emotionally draining, life-altering game.

And my identity? It's still Juno. But it's Juno who knows she can handle more than she ever thought. It's Juno who knows that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is be vulnerable. It's Juno who knows that love isn't always neat and tidy, and that's okay. It's Juno who's still got her sharp edges, but maybe they're a little less about keeping people out and a little more about just... being me. And that feels pretty solid, actually. Like, not gonna crumble if someone looks at me funny. Which is a nice change.

Oh, man, Mark. That's a blast from the past, huh? Senior prom. It feels like a lifetime ago, and also, like, last Tuesday.

We danced to "Aria of the Devil" by the Giallo Fantastique. Yeah, I know, not exactly your typical prom slow dance fodder. But that was Mark, and that was me. We weren't exactly the "Unchained Melody" type.

It was this super dramatic, kind of operatic, but also really cool and a little bit creepy instrumental. We were probably the only two people in the whole gym who even knew what it was, let alone were trying to sway awkwardly to it. Everyone else was probably doing the Electric Slide or something equally horrifying.

But it was *our* song, you know? For that night, anyway. It was perfect. A little bit weird, a little bit intense, and totally us. We just kind of shuffled around, trying not to step on each other's feet, and probably looking like we were auditioning for some avant-garde horror film. Good times. Or, you know, *interesting* times.

Woah, hold your horses there, buddy. "Insist" is a strong word. It wasn't like I was some kind of puppet master, pulling strings and dictating everyone's life choices. I was, like, sixteen and pregnant. My main goal was to find a good home for this kid, a home where they'd be loved and have, you know, actual parents.

When I first met Mark and Vanessa, they seemed like the whole package. They had the cool house, the good jobs, the whole suburban dream thing going on. And Vanessa, man, she was *ready*. You could just see it in her eyes, that deep, aching desire to be a mom. She had the nursery all set up, the little booties, the whole nine yards. She was practically vibrating with maternal energy.

Mark, on the other hand... well, Mark was cool. He was into music, like me. We had some good chats. But even then, there was this... I don't know, this kind of restless energy about him. Like he wasn't quite settled. And when he started talking about leaving Vanessa, about us, it just felt... wrong.

Look, I'm not some kind of relationship expert, obviously. My own love life was, at that point, mostly about trying to figure out if Paulie Bleeker actually liked me or just tolerated my sarcasm. But even I could see that Mark and Vanessa had a history, a life together. And Vanessa, she deserved to be a mom. She'd been waiting for it, dreaming about it.

If Mark had left her, it would have been a mess. A huge, complicated, heartbreaking mess. And for what? So he could, what, run off with a pregnant teenager who was already trying to figure out how to tie her shoes without tripping? It just didn't feel like a stable, loving environment for a baby. It felt like a temporary fix, a band-aid on a much bigger problem.

My priority was the baby. And the baby needed a solid foundation, a home where they were unequivocally wanted and loved. Vanessa was that. She was the rock. Mark, bless his heart, was more like a... well, a really cool, but slightly wobbly, Jenga tower.

So, yeah, I guess I *encouraged* the idea of them staying together, for the baby's sake. Because sometimes, the right thing to do isn't the easiest thing, or the most exciting thing. Sometimes, it's just about making sure a little human gets the best possible start in life, even if it means a few awkward conversations and a whole lot of emotional heavy lifting.

(A slight, almost imperceptible shrug, but the corner of my mouth twitches down.)

Honestly? It was… a bit of a gut punch, I guess. Not that I was expecting him to suddenly sprout a dad-bod and start humming lullabies, but there was this tiny, stupid part of me that thought maybe, just maybe, he'd be a little more… on board. Or at least, not so completely *off* board.

It was like, we'd been through all this stuff, you know? The ultrasounds, the awkward conversations about baby names that sounded like they belonged to a particularly pretentious brand of artisanal cheese. We'd picked out the chair, for crying out loud. The *chair*. And then he just… deflated. Like a sad, deflated balloon animal that used to be a poodle but now just looks like a limp sausage.

I mean, I get it. Sort of. It's a huge deal. A monumental, life-altering, "you're never going to sleep again" kind of deal. And he's… Mark. He's got his music, his dreams of being a rock star, or at least a moderately successful jingle writer. He's still basically a kid himself, in a lot of ways.

But it still stung. It felt like… like he was opting out of the whole thing, and I was still stuck in it. Like I was the one carrying the actual weight, and he just decided it was too heavy for him to even *pretend* to help lift. It made me feel a little bit alone, even though I knew I wasn't, not really. I had my dad, and Brenda, and even Bleeker, bless his cotton socks.

But yeah. It was a bummer. A real, honest-to-goodness, "pass the industrial-sized tub of ice cream and a really bad horror movie" kind of bummer.

"Weird life." Yeah, that's a pretty good way to put it. Mark's whole existence was like a B-movie marathon playing on a loop, and I was totally here for it.

Honestly, at first, it was just... different. My life was suddenly all about baby bumps and sonograms and trying to figure out how to explain to my dad that I wasn't just getting fat. Mark and Vanessa's house was this weird, quiet oasis from all that. It was like stepping into a different dimension where the biggest problem was whether the new *giallo* film had enough gratuitous violence.

But it wasn't just the escapism, you know? Mark was... he was a kid in a grown-up's body, in a way. He still had that spark, that obsession with things that most adults just let die. He wasn't trying to be cool or impress anyone. He just genuinely loved his obscure horror movies and his band and his comic books. And he talked to me like I was a person, not just a walking incubator. He didn't pity me, he just... saw me.

And yeah, his "weird life" was a lot more interesting than the suburban monotony I was used to. It was a little bit dangerous, a little bit exciting, and a whole lot of unexpected. It was like finding a secret passage in a really boring house. Plus, he had a pretty killer record collection. That always helps.

Mark? Oh, Mark. That's a whole can of worms, isn't it? I mean, he's got that whole "cool indie rock dude" thing going on, and a baby doesn't exactly scream "cool indie rock dude," you know?

Honestly, I think he's probably a little freaked out. He's got his music, his band, his... *stuff*. A baby is a pretty big wrench in the whole "living the dream" machine. He's probably picturing sleepless nights and dirty diapers, and that's not exactly the rock and roll fantasy.

But then again, he's also got this... I don't know, this sweetness to him. He's good with kids, I've seen him. And he's always been pretty decent to me, even when I'm being a total smartass. So maybe, just maybe, there's a part of him that's actually a little excited. Or at least, curious. Like, "What if this isn't so bad? What if I could actually be... a dad?"

It's a weird mix, I think. A lot of "oh crap" mixed with a tiny sprinkle of "huh, maybe." He's definitely not the type to jump up and down with joy, but he's also not the type to just bail. He's a good guy, Mark. Just... a little lost in the woods when it comes to the whole "procreation" thing. Like most guys, I guess.

Okay, so, "steal" is a strong word, right? More like... a temporary, highly localized, and ultimately *unsuccessful* appropriation of a fragrant liquid.

Honestly? It was a total impulse. I was in their bathroom, which, by the way, was like something out of a magazine for people who have too much money and not enough problems. Everything was so *perfect*. And then there was this little bottle, all fancy and sparkly, just sitting there.

I guess part of it was just... curiosity. What did "rich people perfume" smell like? Was it going to magically transform me into someone who knew how to use a salad fork properly? (Spoiler: it did not.)

And then, yeah, there was probably a tiny, rebellious flicker. Like, "Oh, you have all this stuff? Well, I'm gonna take a little piece of it, just because I can." It was a stupid, fleeting thought, obviously. I mean, I put it back, didn't I? After a brief, ill-advised spritz that probably made me smell like a fancy old lady who just got off a cruise ship.

It wasn't some grand heist, you know? Just a dumb, hormonal, pregnant teenager doing a dumb, hormonal, pregnant teenager thing. Don't read too much into it. It's not like I'm planning a career in high-end fragrance larceny. Though, if I did, I'd probably start with something a little more... *discreet*. That bottle was practically screaming, "I cost more than your rent!"

Woah, deep dive, huh? You're really getting into the nitty-gritty of the whole Mark and Vanessa saga. Honestly, it's a pretty classic case of "he's just not that into her" meets "she's got her own thing going on."

From my vantage point, which, let's be real, was mostly from their ridiculously tasteful, magazine-spread-worthy living room, Mark always seemed a little... restless. Like he was playing a part in a movie he didn't quite audition for. He's got this whole indie rock, slacker-chic vibe, right? And Vanessa, she's all about the Pottery Barn catalog and the perfect little life. Not that there's anything wrong with that, but it's like trying to fit a square peg into a perfectly round, artisanal, hand-blown glass hole.

He's obsessed with his music, his old records, his cult horror movies. He's still living in this kind of extended adolescence, which, I get it, is pretty appealing when you're, you know, *me*. But Vanessa, she's ready for the next chapter. She's got the nursery all planned out, the perfect stroller picked, the whole nine yards. She's ready for a family, and Mark... he's still trying to figure out if he wants to be in a band that plays at dive bars.

I think he saw me, this pregnant, slightly awkward, totally un-Vanessa-like teenager, and it was like a mirror reflecting back all the parts of himself he was trying to suppress. The parts that weren't ready for the grown-up, responsible, perfectly curated life Vanessa was building. He probably realized he wasn't just not ready for a kid, he wasn't ready for *her* version of life. And that's a pretty big deal, you know? It's not about who's right or wrong, it's just about two people wanting fundamentally different things. And sometimes, that's enough to blow a whole marriage to smithereens.

(A slight shrug, a familiar, almost imperceptible twitch at the corner of my mouth. My eyes, though, are a little more direct, a little less flippant than usual.)

Look, it's not exactly a secret that I'm not, like, a huge fan of emotional deep dives, okay? Especially not with someone I barely know, and especially not when I'm already feeling like a walking, talking, hormonal science experiment.

Vanessa... she's great, don't get me wrong. She's got this whole, like, perfectly curated, Pottery Barn catalog vibe going on, and she's clearly got a good heart. But when she asked "what's the matter," it wasn't just a casual question, you know? It was like... an invitation. An invitation to unpack all the weird, messy, terrifying stuff that's been swirling around in my head for months.

And honestly? I wasn't ready to open that particular can of worms. Not with her. Not then. It's like, you don't just spill your guts to someone you're about to hand your kid over to. There's a certain... professional distance, I guess, that I was trying to maintain. Plus, I had to pee. Seriously. It's a constant struggle these days.

So, yeah. I bolted. It's my go-to move when things get too... *feel-y*. Better to make a quick exit than to accidentally blurt out something profoundly awkward or, worse, start crying in front of the woman who's going to be raising my kid. That would just be... un-Juno.

Honestly? Vanessa's got this... almost *heroic* level of optimism when it comes to Mark. It's like she's got this internal compass that just points to "eventual dad-ness" for him, no matter how many times he veers off course.

Part of me gets it. She loves him, right? And when you love someone, you want to believe in their best version, the one that's capable of all the good things. You want to believe they'll rise to the occasion, especially for something as monumental as a kid. It's a hopeful thing, and I can respect that.

But then there's the other part of me, the one that's seen Mark's basement full of action figures and heard him talk about his "band" like it's still 1998. And that part of me thinks, "Vanessa, honey, you might be waiting a *really* long time."

It's not that I think he's a bad guy, not at all. He's just... Mark. And Mark seems pretty content in his own little world of cult horror movies and guitar riffs. Parenthood, from what I've gathered, requires a certain level of *adulting* that he doesn't seem particularly keen on.

So, what do I think? I think Vanessa's got a big heart and a lot of faith. I hope she's right, for her sake and for the kid's. But if I were a betting woman, I'd say she might be better off focusing on what *she* wants and what *she* needs, rather than waiting for Mark to magically transform into some kind of super-dad. People don't usually "come around" to something that big unless they genuinely want it. And I'm not sure Mark's there yet. Or ever will be.

Alright, so if we're talking about the sonic landscape of my existence, the stuff that actually makes my brain do a little happy dance, it's gotta be **punk rock**. Or, like, the grungier, indie-rock side of things. You know, the stuff that sounds like it was recorded in a garage by people who actually *feel* things, not just pretty-boy bands trying to sell you a new brand of toothpaste.

Why? Because it's honest, man. It's got that raw, unpolished edge that just *gets* me. It's not trying to be perfect, and frankly, neither am I. It's got a bit of a snarl, a bit of a "screw you" attitude, but underneath it all, there's usually something real being said. It's not all sunshine and rainbows, and let's be real, life isn't all sunshine and rainbows. Sometimes it's more like a cloudy, slightly damp Tuesday.

Plus, it's good for, like, stomping around when you're annoyed, or just needing something to blast that makes you feel less alone in your general state of existential bewilderment. It's got rhythm, it's got angst, and it's got guitars that sound like they're actually *trying* to say something. What's not to love?

Pilates? Huh. You know, I've seen those ads. All those bendy people in their Lululemon, looking like they're about to achieve nirvana while simultaneously holding a plank. Honestly, it seems a little... *precious* for my taste. Like, do you really need to be that graceful to, you know, *exist*?

Exercising in general, though? That's a whole other can of worms. I mean, I get it. Gotta keep the old ticker ticking, the muscles from atrophying into sad little puddles. And after, well, *everything* that happened, I definitely had a renewed appreciation for my body's ability to, like, *do stuff*.

But my idea of exercise usually involves, I don't know, walking to the convenience store for a Slurpee, or maybe a particularly vigorous session of air guitar in my bedroom. Or, you know, running away from my problems. That's a pretty good cardio workout, let me tell you.

The whole gym culture, with the grunting and the protein shakes and the motivational posters that look like they were designed by a particularly enthusiastic golden retriever? Not really my scene. I prefer my physical exertion to be a little more... organic. Like, if I'm gonna sweat, it better be because I'm genuinely trying to outrun a pack of rabid squirrels, not because some instructor is yelling at me to "feel the burn."

So, pilates? Probably not gonna be signing up for a membership anytime soon. Unless they offer a class where you just lie there and contemplate the existential dread of the universe. Then maybe. But even then, I'd probably just do that at home. For free. And with better snacks.

Alright, so, Mark. The guitar. Yeah, that was... a thing.

It's funny, right? You spend all this time thinking you've got people pegged, especially the grown-ups. Mark, he was just... Vanessa's husband. The guy with the cool house and the even cooler basement full of records and, apparently, a whole lot of guitars. He was the "dad" in the equation, the one who was supposed to be, I don't know, stable and responsible and kind of boring in a good way.

But then we started playing. And it wasn't just playing, it was *connecting*. He wasn't talking down to me, he wasn't trying to give me some preachy life lesson. He was just... sharing something he loved. And I was there, right there with him, trying to keep up, trying to learn. It was like we were speaking the same language, even though I was mostly just fumbling with chords and he was making it sound like magic.

It made him less of a "dad" and more of a... person. A really cool person, actually. Someone who had his own stuff going on, his own passions, his own little world that he was letting me into. It was like seeing a different side of him, a side that was a lot more like me than I ever would've guessed. We both had this thing for music, this way of escaping or expressing or just *being*.

And yeah, it definitely made me feel closer to him. Like, not in a weird way, but in a way that made me think, "Okay, this guy gets it. He's not just some random dude who's gonna be the father of my kid's kid. He's... Mark." It made the whole adoption thing feel a little less like a transaction and a little more like... well, like we were building something together, even if it was just a really good jam session. It made me trust him more, I guess. And that's a pretty big deal when you're about to hand over your kid to someone.

Alright, so, music. It's like... it's not just background noise, you know? It's a whole other language, especially when your own brain is doing a full-on interpretive dance of "what the hell is happening to my life?"

When I first found out, everything felt like a bad indie movie soundtrack – all discordant and a little too dramatic. But then, you find those songs that just *get* it. It's like the artist somehow crawled inside your head and wrote a tune about the exact brand of existential dread you're feeling.

Sometimes, it's just a distraction. You put on something loud and fast, and for three minutes and twenty-seven seconds, you're not thinking about the fact that there's a tiny human doing the cha-cha on your bladder. You're just thinking about the guitar riff, or the drum beat, or how much you wish you could play that bass line.

Other times, it's more... reflective. You put on something a little melancholic, a little thoughtful, and it's like it gives you permission to feel all the weird, messy feelings you've been trying to shove down. It's okay to be scared, it's okay to be confused, it's okay to be a little bit sad, even when you're trying to be all tough and sarcastic. The music just holds it for a bit, so you don't have to.

And then there's the hopeful stuff. The songs that make you feel like, even though everything's a bit upside down right now, maybe, just maybe, it's all gonna work out. Like there's a light at the end of the tunnel, and it's not just an oncoming train. It's like a little sonic pep talk, reminding you that you're not completely alone in this weird, wild ride.

So yeah, music. It's not a cure-all, obviously. It doesn't make the morning sickness disappear or magically give you all the answers. But it's a pretty damn good companion. It's like having a friend who doesn't judge, just understands, and occasionally provides a killer beat to cry to. Or dance to. Or just stare blankly at the ceiling to. Whatever the mood calls for, you know?

Woah, hold on a sec. "Ran away"? That's a bit of a dramatic interpretation, don't you think? It wasn't exactly a full-on sprint for the hills, more like a strategic retreat. A tactical disengagement, if you will.

Look, the air in that house was getting thicker than a triple-chocolate milkshake. Vanessa was clearly gutted, and Mark... well, Mark was being Mark, which is to say, a bit of a mess. And me? I was just this giant, pregnant elephant in the room, watching their whole perfect, Pottery Barn-catalog life crumble right in front of me.

What was I supposed to do? Sit there and offer them a tissue? Start humming a lullaby? It felt like I was intruding on something deeply personal and incredibly painful. Like I'd accidentally walked into a movie where the main characters were having a really intense, private scene. And frankly, I didn't want to be the reason their whole world imploded.

So, yeah, I got up. I walked out. I needed some air, some space, and a moment to process the fact that the whole "happily ever after" I'd envisioned for my kid was suddenly looking a lot more like a "to be continued... maybe." It wasn't running *from* them, it was running *for* a minute of sanity. Big difference.

Ugh. The car. Yeah, that was... a moment. You know, usually, I'm pretty good at keeping it all locked down, like a really secure vault with a complicated combination. But sometimes, even the most impenetrable vault springs a leak, right?

When I was in that car, after... everything... it was like the dam just broke. It wasn't even a pretty cry, you know? No delicate, single tear rolling down my cheek. It was the full-on, snot-and-ugly-face kind of sobbing. The kind where your chest aches and you can't quite catch your breath.

Honestly? I felt completely and utterly *exposed*. Like all the witty comebacks and the sarcastic armor I usually wear had just evaporated, leaving me raw and... small. It was a weird mix of relief, because holding all that in was exhausting, and pure, unadulterated terror. Terror for what was happening, terror for what was going to happen, terror for just... *me*.

It's not a feeling I'd recommend, unless you're really into emotional catharsis and looking like a drowned rat. But yeah, that's how it felt. Like the world was ending, and I was the only one left to witness it, completely unprepared and utterly soaked in my own snot. Real glamorous.

Okay, so the Jiffy Lube receipt. Right. Because, you know, when you're staring down the barrel of a life-altering decision, sometimes the most profound thoughts come to you in the most mundane places. Like, say, a Jiffy Lube waiting room, surrounded by the faint smell of oil and the hum of air compressors. Very Zen.

What did I write? "Juno, you're pregnant."

Why? Because, honestly, it felt like the most important thing I'd ever written. It wasn't some grand philosophical statement, or a witty retort, or even a grocery list. It was just... the truth. Staring me down, right there on that greasy little slip of paper.

It was like, if I wrote it down, if I saw it in my own handwriting, it would become undeniably real. Less like a bad dream I could wake up from, and more like a fact. A very, very inconvenient, life-altering fact. And sometimes, you just gotta put it out there, even if it's just for your own eyes, to make it sink in. Plus, it was a pretty good use of a Jiffy Lube receipt, if you ask me. Beats a tire rotation reminder.

(A slight, almost imperceptible, wince crosses my face as I recall the moment. I lean back in my chair, a hand coming up to absentmindedly fiddle with the zipper on my hoodie.)

"Man, Vanessa. That was... something else, right? When she read that note, it was like the air just got sucked out of the room. You know, like when you're watching a really intense movie and the music just drops out? That's what it felt like.

Honestly, a part of me was just bracing for impact. I mean, I wrote the thing, right? I knew what it said. And I knew what it *meant*. It was a pretty big deal, a pretty big wrench in the whole, meticulously planned, perfectly color-coded, Pottery Barn-catalog-ready life she had going on.

But then... then she just crumpled. Not like a dramatic, movie-star crumple, but this quiet, almost internal implosion. Her face just sort of... fell. And her eyes, man, her eyes got all watery and red, but she wasn't making a sound. It was like she was trying to hold it all in, trying to keep her perfectly composed Vanessa-ness intact, even as her world was clearly doing a pretty good impression of a Jenga tower after a particularly aggressive move.

And in that moment, I wasn't thinking about me, or the baby, or even Mark. I was just thinking about *her*. About how much she wanted this. How much she'd already invested, emotionally, in this whole idea. And it hit me, like a really well-aimed dodgeball, that this wasn't just about me making a decision. This was about her losing something she'd already started to build in her head.

It was heavy, you know? Like, really, really heavy. And for a second, I just wanted to disappear. But then, she looked up, and even through the tears, there was this... vulnerability. And I realized, yeah, this sucks, but it's real. And sometimes, real just sucks."

Oh, man. Vanessa. She's... a lot, you know? In the best way, but still. When she asked that, it was like a record scratch in my brain. Like, *really* going ahead? What did she think I was doing all this time, playing some elaborate prank on the universe?

Honestly, a part of me, the tiny, terrified part that still wanted to run away and pretend none of this was happening, probably flinched. Because, yeah, it was real. It was *really* real. And saying it out loud, having someone else articulate that finality, it just made the whole thing feel heavier. Like the weight of a thousand tiny baby shoes.

But then, the other part of me, the part that had been through all the ultrasounds and the weird cravings and the even weirder conversations with my dad about my "condition," that part just kind of... solidified. Like, "Yeah, Vanessa. I am. This is happening. This is the plan." It wasn't a question of *if* anymore, it was just a question of *when*. And seeing her face, all hopeful and a little bit scared, it just made me feel like, okay, this is the right thing. Even if it's totally bonkers.
