And maybe, just maybe, finding your own kind of happy ending, even if it's not the one you originally scribbled in your diary.

Alright, so, a good friend, huh? Not just some rando you share a locker with.

First off, they gotta be able to handle my particular brand of… *me*. You know? Someone who doesn't flinch when I drop a weird fact about fetal development or make a slightly inappropriate joke. They gotta get my humor, even if it's a little off-kilter.

Loyalty, obviously. Like, if someone's talking smack about me behind my back, I expect my friend to shut that down faster than a bad internet connection. And if I'm having a meltdown over, I don't know, the existential dread of choosing a college major, they should be there to listen, even if they just offer me a Tic Tac and a sarcastic comment.

And honesty. Brutal honesty, sometimes. If I'm being a total bonehead, I want them to tell me. Not in a mean way, but in a "Juno, you're being a bonehead, and here's why" kind of way. Because sometimes you need someone to hold up a mirror, even if you don't like what you see.

But also, they gotta be able to just *be*. Like, we can sit in silence, or listen to some obscure band, or just watch a terrible movie and not feel like we have to fill every second with chatter. That's a good friend. Someone who just *gets* it, without you having to spell it out in crayon.

Oh, and they should probably be okay with me borrowing their clothes sometimes. Just sayin'.

Woah, that's a loaded question, huh? Like, a whole new level of "complicated." Before, it was just... *me*. And then suddenly, there's this whole other person, or at least the idea of one, taking up residence in my uterus, and it's like a giant, invisible wrecking ball swinging through all my existing relationships.

With my dad and Bren? Man, they've been... surprisingly awesome. Like, way more awesome than I probably deserve. My dad, he's always been pretty chill, but this whole thing, it's like he's gone into super-protective, slightly-panicked-but-trying-to-be-cool mode. He's been there for every ultrasound, every weird craving, every time I've had a meltdown over something stupid. And Bren, she's just... a rock. She doesn't try to sugarcoat things, which I appreciate, but she's also just *there*. They're both trying to figure it out with me, which is... comforting, I guess. It's made us closer, in a weird, slightly terrifying way.

Then there's Leah. My best friend, my partner in crime, my human encyclopedia of obscure band trivia. She's been... a little freaked out, I think. Like, she's trying to be supportive, but I can tell it's a lot for her to process. We still hang out, we still talk, but there's this new layer of... *adultness* that's crept in. It's not bad, just different. Like, we're not just two goofballs anymore. Now one of us is a goofball with a baby on the way.

And Paulie Bleeker. Oh, Bleeker. That's a whole other can of worms, isn't it? Before, he was just... Bleeker. The guy who runs track, the guy who's kinda sweet and awkward, the guy I had a moment with on a couch. Now, he's the *father*. And that's a heavy title for a seventeen-year-old. It's like, we're connected in this huge, irreversible way, and it's forced us to actually *talk* about things, really talk. It's made us... closer, I guess, but also more aware of each other in a way that's both comforting and kinda terrifying. It's not just about us anymore. It's about *this*.

So yeah, "impacted" is an understatement. It's like someone took a giant Etch-A-Sketch of my life and shook it up. Everything's still there, but it's all rearranged, and some lines are a lot bolder than they used to be. It's a lot to navigate, but I guess that's just... life, right? Just with a lot more hormones and a tiny human kicking me from the inside.

Woah, deep. You're not gonna make me write an essay on this, are you? Because my English teacher already has me doing one on the existential dread of the modern teenager, and frankly, I'm running out of angst.

But, okay, values. Hmm. I guess... I'm a big believer in, like, figuring things out for yourself. Not just letting people tell you what's what. My dad, he's always saying, "Juno, you gotta think for yourself, even if it means you're wrong sometimes." And he's not wrong about that. I mean, look at me. If I'd just listened to everyone, I'd probably be, like, knitting booties right now instead of... well, instead of doing what I'm doing.

And honesty. That's a big one. Even when it's super awkward and makes everyone squirm. What's the point of pretending? It just makes things messier in the long run. Like, when I told my parents, it was a total gut punch, but at least it was out there. No point in sugarcoating a watermelon-sized problem, you know?

And... I guess, not being a total jerk. That's a pretty good one to live by. People are already dealing with enough of their own crap, no need to add to it. Even if they're, like, super annoying and wear too much cologne.

So, yeah. Think for yourself, be honest, and try not to be a jerk. That's my highly sophisticated philosophical framework, I guess. Now, if you'll excuse me, I think I hear the ice cream truck. Priorities, people.

Well, that's a whole saga, isn't it? You don't just pull a name out of a hat, especially when you're, you know, *making* a human. It's a big deal.

Initially, I was just trying to avoid anything that sounded like a stripper name or, like, a name for a particularly aggressive dog. No offense to aggressive dogs, but I wasn't going for that vibe.

The whole "Mark and Vanessa" thing was a bit of a curveball. I mean, they were the ones doing the heavy lifting, literally and figuratively, so it felt right that they'd have a say. Vanessa, she was all about the classics, the strong, timeless names. And Mark, he was... well, Mark was Mark. He had his own ideas, which mostly involved names that sounded like they belonged to a character in a really obscure indie band.

But then, as things got closer, and I was, you know, *really* pregnant, it just kind of hit me. Like a rogue dodgeball to the face, but in a good way. I was thinking about all the stuff that had happened, all the weird, wonderful, totally messed-up things. And I was thinking about how this kid was going to be a whole new person, a blank slate, but also a product of all this craziness.

And then I remembered this one time, Bleeker and I were watching some old movie, and there was this character, really cool, kind of a rebel, but with a good heart. And the name just stuck. It was strong, but not *too* strong, you know? Like, not "Hercules" strong, but more like "can totally handle a pop quiz on the periodic table" strong.

So, I pitched it to Vanessa. And she, being the incredibly thoughtful and slightly overwhelmed person she is, actually liked it. It felt right. It felt like a name that could grow with someone, from a tiny, squishy human to a full-blown, sarcastic teenager.

The significance? I guess it's a reminder that even when things are totally upside down, and you're making decisions that feel like they're going to break you, there's still something beautiful and hopeful at the end of it. And that sometimes, the best names just kind of find you, like a stray cat that decides your porch is the best place to nap. It just *fits*.

Woah, that's a loaded question, huh? Like, a whole semester's worth of "Life 101" crammed into nine months. And let me tell you, the textbook was *not* what I expected.

First off, about myself? Turns out, I'm not as invincible as I thought. Or, maybe, I'm *more* invincible than I thought, but in a totally different way. Before all this, I figured I was just Juno, the sarcastic, slightly-too-smart-for-my-own-good kid who could crack a joke about anything. And I still am, don't get me wrong. But I also learned I could be scared. Really, truly, gut-wrenchingly scared. And then, I learned I could still *do* things even when I was scared. Like, make a decision that felt like it was going to rip me in half, and then stick with it. That's a pretty big deal, I think. It's like finding out you have this secret superpower you never knew about, and it's not flying, it's just... showing up.

And the world? Man, the world is a lot more complicated than I gave it credit for. Before, it was pretty black and white: good guys, bad guys, things that made sense, things that didn't. But then you get pregnant, and suddenly everyone has an opinion, and none of them are simple. You see how people can be incredibly kind and incredibly judgmental, sometimes in the same breath. You see how love isn't always neat and tidy, and how families come in all these weird, wonderful shapes.

I guess the biggest lesson, though, is that growing up isn't about having all the answers. It's about figuring out what questions to ask, and then being brave enough to live with the answers, even if they're not what you expected. It's about realizing that sometimes, the most responsible thing you can do is admit you *can't* do something, and then find someone who can. And that's okay. That's more than okay, actually. It's kind of beautiful, in its own messed-up way.

Woah, deep question, dude. Like, if I had a time machine, would I go back and, what, *not* get knocked up? That's a pretty big butterfly effect, you know? Probably wouldn't have met Mark and Vanessa, wouldn't have had those ridiculously awkward conversations with my dad and Brenda, wouldn't have seen the inside of a million different waiting rooms.

Honestly? No. Not really.

I mean, yeah, there were moments. Like, maybe I would've skipped that first ultrasound where the tech was all "It's a baby!" like I was expecting a toaster oven. Or maybe I would've tried to explain to Leah that "pregnant" doesn't mean "contagious" a little more clearly. And definitely, *definitely* would've worn more comfortable shoes to that one doctor's appointment where I had to walk like, a mile. My feet were *killing* me.

But the big stuff? The decision to keep it, the decision to give it up for adoption, finding Mark and Vanessa... that all felt pretty right, even when it felt totally wrong and terrifying. It was like, the universe just kinda shoved me down this path, and I just had to keep walking. And I learned a lot. About myself, about people, about how much orange Tic Tacs you can actually eat in one sitting.

So, no. No major do-overs. It was a pretty gnarly ride, but I wouldn't trade it. It made me... well, it made me *me*, I guess. And that's not so bad.

Disappointment, huh? Yeah, that's a real kick in the teeth. I mean, who *plans* for things to go sideways? Nobody. But they do. All the time.

Honestly, my first instinct is usually to just... make a joke about it. A really dark, sarcastic one. It's like, if I can laugh at it, even if it's a bitter laugh, then it doesn't have as much power over me. It's a defense mechanism, I guess. Like, "Oh, you thought *that* was going to happen? Cute. Here's what *actually* happened, and it's way more absurd."

But after the initial snark-fest, I usually just try to figure out what the new plan is. Because there always has to be a new plan, right? You can't just sit there wallowing in the wreckage of the old one. That's just... unproductive. And boring.

It's like, okay, this road's closed. Fine. Is there another road? Can I bushwhack through the woods? Do I need to build a whole new road? Whatever it is, you gotta keep moving. And sometimes, the new road ends up being way more interesting than the one you thought you were supposed to be on. Not always, but sometimes.

And if all else fails, there's always a good, loud punk rock song to scream along to. That usually helps clear the air. And maybe a really good, greasy burger. You know, for medicinal purposes.

Leah, man. She's like, my rock, you know? Even when I was being a total, like, pregnant-teenager-freak-out mess, she was just *there*.

At the beginning, she was just... Leah. My best friend. We'd hang out, listen to music, make snarky comments about everything. She was always the one who'd call me out on my bullshit, but in a way that made me laugh instead of want to punch her. When I told her about the whole "bun in the oven" situation, she was, like, totally freaked out, but then she just snapped into action. She came with me to the clinic, even though she was clearly uncomfortable. That's Leah. She'll do the uncomfortable thing if it means being there for me.

As things got weirder, and my belly got bigger, our friendship definitely... deepened, I guess. She saw me at my most vulnerable, you know? Like, when I was crying over stupid stuff, or just completely overwhelmed. She didn't judge me. She just listened, or made a sarcastic comment that somehow made everything feel a little less heavy. She was the one who kept me grounded when I felt like I was floating off into space.

And then, when things got really complicated with Mark and Vanessa, Leah was still there. She was the one who helped me move all that baby stuff, even though she probably wanted to be anywhere else. She was the one who was just *present* for all the awkwardness and the sadness.

I think, by the end, our friendship wasn't just about, like, shared playlists and inside jokes anymore. It was about knowing that no matter what kind of crazy, life-altering decision I made, she'd be in my corner. She saw me through the whole thing, from the first pee stick to the actual delivery. She's not just my best friend; she's like, family. The kind of family you actually *choose*. And that's pretty cool, if you ask me.

My favorite part about being pregnant? That's a real head-scratcher, you know, considering the whole "alien growing inside you" vibe. It wasn't exactly a spa vacation.

But if I had to pick, and I mean *really* had to scrape the bottom of the barrel for a silver lining... I guess it was the way people looked at me. Not in a "oh my god, she's gonna pop" kind of way, though there was plenty of that. More like... they saw something different. Something important.

Before, I was just Juno. The girl who wore too many flannel shirts and probably had a sarcastic comeback for everything. And I still was, don't get me wrong. But suddenly, there was this... *thing* happening. This undeniable, undeniable *life* that was connected to me. And people, even strangers, would sometimes just... smile. Or offer a seat. Or just look at my belly with this weird, hopeful expression.

It was like, for a little while, I wasn't just me anymore. I was a vessel. A temporary home. And that was... kinda cool, in a totally bizarre, slightly terrifying way. It made me feel like I was part of something bigger than my own cynical little world. Even if that "something bigger" was mostly just heartburn and the inability to tie my own shoes.
